tools.detail: Mallet is a Java based library and command line framework that provides statistical and machine learning tools for use with natural language processing.
tools.name: Mallet

tools.detail: Abbot is a free tool for converting multiple XML texts with multiple markup schema into a common interoperable file, offered by the MONK (Metadata Offer New Knowledge) Project. It can also read an XML schema file and output procedures, and use them to convert other files into valid XML in alignment with the target schema. While Abbot focusses on TEI, it has been designed to flexibly accomodate other standards and can transform texts into any XML schema required.
tools.name: Abbot

tools.detail: TACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools) is a historically important text analysis and retrieval system that was developed from 1986 to 1989 at the University of Toronto in cooperation with IBM and remained in use into the 1990s. It was designed to run in MS-DOS and permitted inquiries on text databases in a number of European languages. Originally available on two 1.44MB floppy disks, the full fileset is now available for free download.
tools.name: TACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools)

tools.detail: SimpleTCT (Simple Text Comparison Tool) is a free Java-based text comparison tool offered by Open Digital Arts & Humanities Tools (OpenDAHT). It offers a simplified management environment that enables users to display .rtf files, in which they may define themes, highlight passages and add researcher notes. The modified document can then be exported for later use.
tools.name: SimpleTCT

tools.detail: TUSTEP (Tubingen System of Text Processing Tools) is a free, open source, widely-used toolbox for text processing. It is aimed at scholarly audiences, can work with texts in both latin and non-latin scripts, and is primarily designed for humanites applications. Its modules include data capture, information retrieval, text collation, text analysis, sorting and ordering, rule-based textual manipulation, data export and typesetting. The user manual is only available in German at this time. This tool has been in continuous development since the 1960s.
tools.name: TUSTEP

tools.detail: Concordance is a commerical text analysis and concordance tool originally developed for the Humanities (formerly available via the University of Dundee School of Humanities). It offers features for text analysis, word lists, indexes, full concordances, word frequencies and more. A free trial version is available.
tools.name: Concordance

tools.detail: GINGER II is a word-sense disambiguator for English, offering a new approach to the algorithm developed for GINGER I. It directly extracts semantic disambiguation rules from dictionary example phrases, and semantically tags, syntactically parses and disambiguates those examples. This legacy tool has no affiliated web site and is no longer available.
tools.name: GINGER II

tools.detail: Pattern (CLiPS) is a web mining module for Python designed for computational linguistic and psycholinguistic research. It integrates tools for data retrieval from search engines, social media, web spiders and individual websites, and can accomplish text analysis, natural language processing and data visualization.
tools.name: Pattern (CLiPS)

tools.detail: INTEX is a linguistic development environment active until 2005. It includes large-coverage dictionaries and grammers, can parse texts of several million words in real-time, and tools to create and maintain large-coverage lexical resources, morphological and syntactic grammars, build lemmatized concordances and indices of large texts and identified semantic units.
tools.name: INTEX

tools.detail: NETMET is a tool for generating and interpreting metaphors designed to run in DOS. Though this tool is no longer under development, it is still available for download. It includes a number of sample input metaphor files and is designed to be modified and improved as needed by the user.
tools.name: NETMET

tools.detail: Micro-EYEBALL is a microprocessor version of the English language parser developed in the 1970s. This historically important legacy tool could also provide statistical descriptions of many linguistic features of a text. This tool is no longer available, and does not have a web presence.
tools.name: Micro-EYEBALL

tools.detail: Collate was a program designed for scholars concerned with the difficulties of medieval vernacular traditions. It aimed to help scholars with the preparation of critical editions, and could collate up to a hundred texts. Collate was also capable of handling marked up text. It was available for Macintosh only, and could be purchased directly from its creator.
tools.name: Collate: Interactive Collation of Large Textual Traditions

tools.detail: XTRACT was a tool for lexical collocation developed by Frank Smadja, then of Columbia University. It was designed to use statistical techniques to identify collocations of aribitrary length, and to generate syntactic relationships between words. This tool is no longer available and does not have a web presence.
tools.name: XTRACT

tools.detail: JConcorder is Java software for building and managing word catalogues, originally released for the Macintosh as Concorder / Le Concordeur. Amongst its features are functions for listing and cataloguing words, generating concordances, exporting concordances and graphing frequencies. The original version is also available for download, but requires a legacy Macintosh operating system to run.
tools.name: JConcorder

tools.detail: PC-KIMMO is a tool for morphological parsing available since 1985. It is designed to generate and/or parse words, for use by computational linguists, descriptive linguists and others interested in natural language processing. Though this tool is no longer being actively developed, it is still available for download, as is its documentation.
tools.name: PC-KIMMO

tools.detail: URICA! II  (User Response Interactive Collation Assistant) was an interactive collation program for the Macintosh. It semi-automated text collation, and assisted text comparison by 'tagging' variants or automatically reconciling small differences. URICA! II built upon the foundation of URICA!, the first iteration of the program.
tools.name: URICA! II

tools.detail: VINCI is a natural language generation environment, first introduced in 1986 and with a sustained web presence. It provides linguists with a collection of linguist-friendly metalanguages for modelling natural language. It can generate sentences and words according to user specifications to assist in the study of linguistic phenomena.
tools.name: VINCI

tools.detail: Micro-OCP (Oxford Concordance Program) was a major and historically important textual analysis tool for microprocessor computers. It enabled users to generate concordances, word lists and indexes, in addition to facilitating text markup in COCOA or other markup languages. Micro-OCP was written in FORTRAN, ran primarily in a DOS environment and could be ported to other operating systems including UNIX.
tools.name: Micro-OCP

tools.detail: FINNMORF was a tool for generating full lexical paradigms for Finnish words. It modelled Finnish morphological competence, to facilitate identification of the most likely forms of a word within its context. Although the program could not select the correct form from context, the complexity of Finnish required sophisticated modelling to correctly determine the possible root form of a given word. As such, FINNMORF represented a significant contribution to computational linguistics.
tools.name: FINNMORF

tools.detail: WordCruncher is long-standing text indexing, retrieval and analysis program offered by Brigham Young University. Its functions include tagging, contextual searching, collocation and analytical reporting, and its development has been active since the 1980s.
tools.name: WordCruncher

tools.detail: DV-COLL (Donne Variorum Textual Collation Program) is a historically important textual collation program first introduced in the 1980s and maintained into the present. It was originally designed to assist in creating a digitized corpus of the works of John Donne, and has been opened to other researchers for collecting, comparing and analyzing the works of other poets.
tools.name: DV-COLL (Donne Variorum Textual Collation Program)

tools.detail: CLOC is a general purpose text analysis package originally offered by the University of Birmingham Computing Centre in the late 1970s, and now avaiable for download. It can generate concordances, collocates and word lists for a text. This tool was developed in Fortran.
tools.name: CLOC

tools.detail: WORDS was a text analysis program library for content analysis developed by Howard P. Iker at the University of Rochester. It identified major content themes, and generated word frequencies and collocations, and was sufficiently complex to require a 200-page user manual. This program is no longer available and does not have a web presence.
tools.name: WORDS

tools.detail: KLIC (Key Letter in Context) was a program for graphological anaylsis particularly useful to scholars analyzing the language of medieval texts, created by Grace B. Logan of the Waterloo Arts Computing Office. It assisted in determining where different spelllings represent different pronunciations, and when they are variant spellings of the same word.
tools.name: KLIC (Key Letter in Context)

tools.detail: LEXICO was an interactive system designed to assist lexographers in text analysis. It assisted in storing, editing and concording texts, lemmatizing word lists and generating 'slips' containing a single word with its lemma, context and source.
tools.name: LEXICO

tools.detail: COCOA was a program and markup language for generating word counts and concordances written in FORTRAN, from the University College Cardiff and the Atlas Computer Laboratory. It produced keyword-in-context concordances and word frequency profiles for texts, and was considered to be a powerful, highly flexible program for punched card computers.
tools.name: COCOA

tools.detail: SELECT (Sum and Evaluate the Largest Exponentiated Correlation Terms) was a computer program for identifying associationally rich words for content analysis emerging from the WORDS research program developed in the 1970s. Although historically important, SELECT is no longer available and does not have an web presence.
tools.name: SELECT (Sum and Evaluate the Largest Exponentiated Correlation Terms)

tools.detail: Meandre is a graphical programming language for creating text analysis flows, built on top of the Seasr infrastructure. Meandre uploads its flows to a Seasr server where they can be accessed and used by anyone who can access the server.
tools.name: Meandre

tools.detail: Massive Pixel Environment (formerly Most Pixels Ever: Cluster Edition) is a library from the Texas Advanced Computing Center's A Thousand Words Project, inspired by and expanding on the original Most Pixels Ever developed by Daniel Shiffman. It extends Processing sketches to multi-node tile displays, enabling users to display output across multiple systems and displays, at the native resolution of those displays. This allows for a dramatic increase in the amount of data that may be visualized at one time, in comparison to a single-screen display.
tools.name: Massive Pixel Environment

tools.detail: Kaleidoscope is a tool designed to assist users in spotting differences between versions of a text, source files or images. It allows direct comparison of images, texts to be merged into a single edition, and files to be differentiated.
tools.name: Kaleidoscope

tools.detail: Meld is a free, open source tool for comparing files, directories and version-controlled projects developed in Python by Kai Willadsen. It features two- and three-way comparison of files and directories, supports numerous version control systems, and is particularly useful for reviewing changes to code. This tool can be downloaded or run without an install via the command line by copying the source code directly from the repository.
tools.name: Meld

tools.detail: WordSeer is a free, simple to use text analysis tool offered by the University of California Berkeley. It is entirely web based, with tools for search, reading and interrogating, heat maps and frequency. At this time, the only corpus available for exploration is the works of William Shakespeare.
tools.name: WordSeer

tools.detail: GATE (General Architecture for Text Engineering) is free, open source software offered by the University of Sheffield since 1995. It provides a framework for users to gather a corpus, apply an ontology to it, develop markup, automate the application of the markup to the corpus and add tools such as knowledge facet search, ontology browsing or graphing.
tools.name: GATE (General Architecture for Text Engineering)

tools.detail: FRANTEXT is a historically and culturally important database of French literary, philosophical and technical texts with an emphasis on diversity and representation, spanning the Middle Ages to the present, and offered on a subscription basis. This resource is aimed at linguists and literary scholars in the humanities and social sciences, and is notable for its inclusion of a powerful search engine called Stella. Stella is a sophisticated NLP search suite, and includes regular expression search, lemmatization, vocabulary list and entity categorization functions.
tools.name: FRANTEXT / Stella

tools.detail: TACTweb 1.0 is a free, historically important experimental web-based implementation of the TACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools) analysis and retrieval system, utilizing code originally written for TACT 2.0. TACTweb 1.0 is designed to make a TACT TDB database accessible to web users without requiring them to have a copy of TACT themselves. TACTweb 1.0 enables users to query TACT in its query language without having to learn the rest of the system. It is currently available for download, and is intended for install on a server.
tools.name: TACTweb 1.0

tools.detail: Flemm v3.1 is a free, open source tool for lemmatizing and generating inflections for a French text.
tools.name: Flemm v3.1: Analyseur Flexionnel du français pour des corpus étiquetés

tools.detail: CNRTL is a free XUI and Javascript extension for Firefox designed to enable users to access the French lexical CNRTL portal directly within their web browser. With its toolbar, users can also double-click on a word within a webpage to view lexical information for it.
tools.name: CNRTL Extension for Firefox

tools.detail: Pompamo is a free, web based tool for French texts designed to detect candidates for neologisms within a text based on lexical exclusion. Users can apply the built-in lexicon or upload up to six of their own.
tools.name: Pompamo

tools.detail: DériF (Dérivation en Français) is a free, web based morphological analyzer for French. It lemmatizes a text and labels each lemma, out of context, with a grammatical category (noun, verb, adjective, etc.).
tools.name: DériF (Dérivation en Français)

tools.detail: FastKwic is a free concordance tool for French and English texts encoded in ISO-Latin-1 (ISO-8859-1) or UTF-8. It is available for download, and compiles a user-provided lexical resource and applies it when indexing or concording a text.
tools.name: FastKwic

tools.detail: GRIPHOS (General Retrieval and Information Processor for Humanities Oriented Studies) is a historically important suite of programs used extensively within the Museum Computer Network, a shared information management system developed jointly by fifteen New York area museums. Designed by Dr. Jack Heller of New York University's Institute for Computer Research in the Humanities (ICRH) and debuting in 1967, GRIPHOS enabled museums to store, retrieve and apply textual markup to their records.
tools.name: GRIPHOS (General Retrieval and Information Processor for Humanities Oriented Studies)

tools.detail: R is an open source programing language designed for statistical analysis and parallel computing. R began its life as a research project at the University of Aukland, but has since expanded to become a collaborativly run open source project run by the GNU. R has libraries for data import, regular expression data splitting, and visualization of data. R can be run as either a script or as a working environment.
tools.name: R

tools.detail: Trend Miner is a tool designed to enable portable open-source real-time methods for cross-lingual mining and summarizing of large-scale stream media. It combines elements from natural language processing, knowledge-based reasoning, machine learning, economics and political science. It is designed to access and interpret data from sources such as blogs, Facebook and Twitter.
tools.name: Trend Miner

tools.detail: Textal is a text analysis app for the iPhone and iPad offered by the UCL Centre for Digital Humanities. It creates word clouds from texts, websites, tweets and documents, then allows users to explore the statistics and relationships between words in the text. As a tool, it is intended as an introduction to to text analysis while expanding the functionality traditionally implemented in word clouds.
tools.name: Textal

tools.detail: Transana is a free, open source program offered by the University of Wisconsin-Madison Center for Education Research for transcribing and analyzing large collections of video and audio data aimed at academic researchers. It enables users to manually transcribe in a variety of levels of detail, identify and access analytically significant sections of their data, manage collections, organize video clips into categories, apply keywords to sections or clips, generate graphical or textual reports, data mine and share markup.
tools.name: Transana

tools.detail: NVivo is a commercial software package for creating workspaces and corpuses. Its features include importing YouTube videos and comments, social media posts and discussions, web page and PDF capture, multiple language support and support for a wide variety of data formats such as spreadsheets, images, database tables and so on. Users can query their data in a variety of ways, annotate, cross-link and visualize connections, ideas and findings with charts, maps and models
tools.name: NVivo

tools.detail: English Metrics is a free tutorial on English metrics, first written in Hypercard and maintained in a StackRunner version for both OS X and Windows environments. It traces the process of scanning iambic pentameter, and includes reference and exercise material for a range of metrical patterns.
tools.name: English Metrics

tools.detail: The Scandroid is a free program released under the GNU Public License for OS X and Windows environments designed to scan English verse in iambic and anapestic meters, either from a text file or entered by hand. The program explains its process as it scans the text, such as identifying syllables or lexical stresses, or dividing lines into feet, so users can learn about its analysis in addition from its output.
tools.name: The Scandroid 1.1

tools.detail: Prose is a free program for OS X and Windows written in Python and designed to generate random sentences. Originally described in Charles O. Hartman's book Virtual Muse: Experiments in Computer Poetry, it illustrates one approach to using computer programs as adjuncts to the process of composing poetry.
tools.name: Prose (Virtual Muse)

tools.detail: Concord is a free concordance generator written in Python for OS X and Windows XP (a new Windows version is forthcoming). It generates a KWIC concordance entry from a plain-text file for any word or phrase and permits sorting in a variety of ways. Concord can handle large text files, and preliminary testing with the modern Greek alphabet shows it supports non-Latin alphabets. This tool is described in Chris O. Hartman's book Virtual Muse: Experiments in Computer Poetry.
tools.name: Concord, the Interactive Concordance Generator (Virtual Muse)

tools.detail: InTEXT is a legacy, commercial suite of programs designed to supplement web search, intranet management and accomplish variety of document generation, search and manipulation functions. It includes natural language query, full-text search and retrieval and an intelligent document organizer. It runs in Windows NT and UNIX.
tools.name: InTEXT

tools.detail: MAXQDA is a commercial software package for facilitating qualitative and mixed methods research. It includes a graphical interface for organizing and categorizing data, and can import data in a wide variety of formats, including web formats, images, audio and video and spreadsheets. Data can be encoded in several ways, such as keywords, colours or symbols. It includes visualization and report generation.
tools.name: MAXQDA

tools.detail: LIWC (Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count) is a text analysis program available for purchase. It calculates the degree to which various categories of words are used in a text, and can process texts ranging from e-mails to speeches, poems and transcribed natural language in either plain text or Word formats. A free, minimalist web version is available through the website.
tools.name: LIWC (Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count)

tools.detail: The General Inquirer is a historically important program for content analysis of textual data originally developed in the 1960s by Philip Stone and his colleagues at the Harvard Laboratory of Social Relations. Though the original release used punched cards, a version the program is available by request, and can be obtained by e-mailing Roger Hurwitz from an academic address. A minimalist web version capable of processing small files is also available. The General Inquirer's homepage is maintained in Philip Stone's memory.
tools.name: General Inquirer

tools.detail: WORDij is a free semantic network tool for capturing relationships between words and assigning word-pair link strengths. This information is used as the basis for more sophisticated analysis, such as word network structure mapping. WORDij requires registration for download.
tools.name: WORDij

tools.detail: UCINET is a software package for analyzing network data, available for purchase and with a 90-day trial period. This tool has been in continuous development since the 1980s, and now includes the capacity to gather and analyze social network data.
tools.name: UCINET

tools.detail: CATPAC is a program available for purchase designed to summarize a text's main ideas. It is multilingual and primarily aimed at researchers in the sciences, and can handle large volumes of text. Text must be formatted in ASCII or RTF. The CATPAC website is no longer available or maintained as of 2014. An archived version of the site and its information can be viewed via the Internet Archive.
tools.name: CATPAC

tools.detail: TextQuest is a text analysis program available for purchase. It is designed to conduct analysis ranging from word lists to concordances to content and readability analyses.
tools.name: TextQuest

tools.detail: Minnesota Contextual Content Analysis is a free legacy tool that has been maintained online. It characterizes texts based on relative frequency, and generates statistical analysis from it. It also includes classifications and is designed to handle texts in a wide range of lengths.
tools.name: Minnesota Contextul Content Analysis (MCCA)

tools.detail: WordStat is a commercial software package for content analysis and text mining on natural language text such as interview transcripts. It also includes features for automatic document tagging and classification.
tools.name: WordStat

tools.detail: Profiler Plus is a commercial general-purpose text analysis program based on natural language processing. It supports multiple languages and can output in text, XML and CSV.
tools.name: Profiler Plus

tools.detail: Crawdad is a commercial software package for qualitative data analysis based on natural language processing. It generates a network model of a text and calculates word influence based on its position within the network. It also includes visualization, classification and comparator features. A trial version is available by request. The Crawdad website is no longer maintained or available. It can still be viewed via the Internet Archive.
tools.name: Crawdad Text Analysis Software

tools.detail: Tropes is a legacy commercial text analysis tool now available for free. It is designed for natural language processing and semantic classification, including chronological analysis of sequential pieces of text and summarization. It includes a graphical interface and can generate a variety of hypertext-based graphs.
tools.name: Tropes

tools.detail: Yoshikoder is a free, open source cross-platform content analysis program. It works with text documents to apply basic content analysis in any language, examine KWIC, generate summaries and generate content analysis dictionaries.
tools.name: Yoshikoder

tools.detail: Lexa is a free legacy set of programs for corpus processing. It is designed to tag and lemmatize texts or series of texts. The website for Lexa is no longer maintained or active, but may still be viewed via the Internet Archive.
tools.name: Lexa

tools.detail: TABARI (Text Analysis By Augmented Replacement Instructions) is a legacy open-source successor to the KEDS program, written in C++ and maintained online to the present in an OS X edition. It runs in the Terminal command prompt, and is designed for analyzing short news stories such as wire service reports. It can determine who is acting against whom, the action and extract the date of the release.
tools.name: TABARI (Text Analysis By Augmented Replacement Instructions)

tools.detail: Ethnograph is a long-standing legacy software package, maintained into the present, for quantitative analysis and data management. It contains features for search, applying metadata and conducting corpus analysis.
tools.name: Ethnograph

tools.detail: SALT (Systemic Analysis of Language Transcripts) is a commercial software package for working with large datasets derived from transcripts. It includes transcription tools, text analysis based on natural language processing, content analysis, classification, and statistics. The Research version includes expanded search and metadata functions, and common text analysis functions such as word lists. A trial version is available.
tools.name: SALT (Statistic Analysis of Language Transcripts)

tools.detail: Voyant RezoViz is a free, web-based tool in the Voyant toolset for visualizing the relationships between people, locations and organizations in a text or collection of texts.
tools.name: Voyant RezoViz

tools.detail: TEXTPACK V is a historic collection of interrelated text analysis utilities first released for mainframe computers in the 1970s. With the fifth edition, released in the 1980s, it was ported from FORTRAN to run on PC.
tools.name: TEXTPACK V

tools.detail: INRAC was an early language compiler useful for prototyping natural language processing interfaces, designing conversational systems, and experimental prose and poetry.
tools.name: INRAC Language Compiler

tools.detail: Parser 1.0 was a commercial program running in DOS for analyzing English-language text, aimed at academics and other researchers.
tools.name: Parser 1.0

tools.detail: FANGORN was a historically important programming language designed for linguistic analysis in the humanities.
tools.name: FANGORN

tools.detail: STASEL (Stylistic Treatment at the Sentence Level) is a historically important program designed to analyze text. It was intended for language and style instruction, but had research-based applications.
tools.name: STASEL (Stylistic Treatment at the Sentence Level)

tools.detail: Morfogen, Morffile/Morfword and Inflword were four historicially important interrelated tools offered as and designed to operate as single package. Morfogen is a finite state compiler for morphological analysis, while Morffile and Morfword utilize Morfogen's compiled rules. Morffile searches a text and replaces them with either their base form or a base form followed by morpheme names. Morfword takes a word input by the user and generates its base forms and morpheme names. Inflword generates inflected words.
tools.name: Morfogen, Morffile/Morfword, Inflword (Version 2.0)

tools.detail: E-Parser was a deterministic parsing system with a syntax of 'heuristic rules' derived from a GB-related parsing system.
tools.name: E-Parser

tools.detail: ESTMORF was a historically important morphological analyzer designed specifically for Estonian text. it included stemming, word classification, suffix identification and so forth.
tools.name: ESTMORF

tools.detail: The NITE XML Toolkit (NXT) is an open source toolkit for working with language corpora, particularly useful for multimodal and cross-annotated data sets.
tools.name: NITE XML Toolkit (NXT)

tools.detail: PL/I was an early programming language commonly used for humanities research, developed at a time when most programming languages were not intended to work with strings of text. In addition to direct processing, it was also used to program systems and tools developed specifically for the humanities.
tools.name: PL/I

tools.detail: SNAP was a historically important programming language designed specificially for humanists. It used plain-English syntax, and was particularly suited for automating text processing tasks.
tools.name: SNAP

tools.detail: SOLAR (A Semantically Oriented Lexical ARchive) was a historically important program originally available only over ARPAnet. It facilitated the semantic and conceptual analysis of English-language texts.
tools.name: SOLAR (A Semantically Oriented Lexical ARchive)

tools.detail: OPCOL was an algorithm developed in the mid-1970s for optimizing the efficiency of text collation from a computer science perspective, created by Robert L. Cannon, Jr. of the University of South Carolina.
tools.name: OPCOL

tools.detail: FISHER was a string-handling package for the FORTRAN programming language. It enabled researchers to manipulate characters and character strings with greater ease than FORTRAN permitted by itself.
tools.name: FISHER

tools.detail: Icon is a historically important programming language that builds on SNOBOL to extend its utility to groups like humanists.
tools.name: Icon

tools.detail: REDUX was a natural language processing program for making generalizations from cases such as case studies, legal cases, case histories and so forth. It searched for repeated patterns, and was presented as a metalanguage for the analysis of the behavior of types.
tools.name: REDUX

tools.detail: The Linear Modelling Kit was a tool for modelling structuralist ideas about narrative, intended for use in literature courses.
tools.name: Linear Modelling Kit

tools.detail: ELSE was a historically important tool developed to assist the instruction of French and Danish with sophisticated error analysis.
tools.name: ELSE

tools.detail: Collocate was a tool for language-independent corpus exploration. It interpreted concordances by assessing the significance of co-occuring words.
tools.name: Collocate

tools.detail: Typical was a tool for language-independent corpus exploration. It assessed the significance of co-occuring words in a line and evaluated the significance of the whole line, to help in disambiguating words and finding characteristic example lines.
tools.name: Typical

tools.detail: TATOE (Text Analysis Tool with Object Encoding) was a tool for developing limited-context grammar rules for automated markup.
tools.name: TATOE (Text Analysis Tool with Object Encoding)

tools.detail: SENSE (Self-Expanding linguistic knowledge base from Sense Elicitation) was a historically important natural language processing system particularly useful for word sense disambiguation.
tools.name: SENSE (Self-Expanding linguistic knowledge base from Sense Elicitation)

tools.detail: Prism is a visualization tool that represents texts based on crowdsourced interpretations. Users are encouraged to highlight words in a text according to categories ("facets"). Users' individual interpretations contribute to a visualization combining the interpretations of all users of the text. As such, it reveals patterns in subjective readings of a text.
tools.name: Prism

tools.detail: ARRAS is a historically important tool for analyzing and concording text. It notably provided inspiration for the TACT system.
tools.name: ARRAS

tools.detail: The DM is an environment for studying and annotating images and texts. It enables users to link together images, texts, or fragments of images or texts, such as a textual annotation of an image or text. It is aimed at scholars of English and French literature, art history, and musicology, and to work with digitized Old English, Latin and Old French manuscripts, medieval maps and scrolls.
tools.name: Digital Mappa

tools.detail: The Domeo Annotation Toolkit was an extensible web application for creating and sharing ontology-based stand-off annotations on HTML or XML documents. Users could add annotations manually, or via the tool's full or partial automation options. It also included functions for controlling access authorization and control for both personal and community annotations.
tools.name: Domeo Annotation Toolkit

tools.detail: Quadrigram is an environment for data gathering, query and visualization, based on a visual programming language and intended for users with no experience programming or creating visualizations. At present, it contains 50 different visualizers.
tools.name: Quadrigram

tools.detail: Digitate is a free, open source application for making notes and annotations directly on an image of a cultural artifact such as a manuscript or a painting. Images can also be grouped into projects, saved for later or exported. This application is only available for the iPad.
tools.name: Digitate

tools.detail: AustESE (Australian Electronic Scholarly Editing) is a workbench environment for facilitating the prodiction of electronic scholarly editions. Its features include functions for text import, markup, collation, textual analysis, annotation and tagging.
tools.name: AustESE (Australian Electronic Scholarly Editing)

tools.detail: Circos is a free visualization tool for creating publication-quality infographics and illustrations. Its visualizations are arranged in a circle to facilitate exploring relationships between objects and positions, which also has the benefit of offering a high data-to-ink ratio. Though promoted for the sciences, it is highly flexible and can visualize datasets from a wide variety of fields.
tools.name: Circos

tools.detail: OpenRefine (formerly Google Refine) is a free, open-source tool for working with messy data. It enables users to clean data, transform it between a variety of formats, extend it with web services, and link it to databases. This tool is available for Windows, Mac and Linux.
tools.name: OpenRefine

tools.detail: Classical Text Editor is a tool for scholars working on critical editions or an a text with commentary and translation, to aid in preparing a camera-ready copy or electronic publication. Its features includes but is not limited to collation, text retrieval, XML and HTML export and tagging, and a full range of formatting options. This tool has been in continuous development since 1997.
tools.name: Classical Text Editor

tools.detail: Tesserae is a web-based interface for exploring intertextual parallels. At this stage of the project, it only permits comparison of texts from three curated corpuses, representing selections from canonical Latin, Greek and English literature.
tools.name: Tesserae

tools.detail: Textexture is a free, web-based tool for visualizing texts as a network. The visualization gives a quick visual summary of the text. Clicking on nodes brings up the excerpts the tool has identified as most relivant, and permits users to locate similar texts. Users can upload their own text, or visualize texts from Textexture's library of public texts.
tools.name: Textexture

tools.detail: WordFreak is a free, open-source tool for linguistic annotation. It is designed to support both human and automated annotation of linguistic data, and learns human corrections of automatically annotated data.
tools.name: WordFreak

tools.detail: UAM CorpusTool is an annotation environment for text corpora in linguistic studies. It includes a graphical schema editor and saves annotations in XML format.
tools.name: UAM CorpusTool

tools.detail: Lexomics is a free tool for analyzing the frequency, distribution and arrangement of words in large-scale patterns.
tools.name: Lexomics

tools.detail: WebLicht is an architecture for creating annotated text corpora. It offers a fully-functional virtual research environment with chains of RESTful web services, each providing a linguistic tool such as format conversion, tokenizing, tagging or parsing. It outputs corpora as XML documents.
tools.name: WebLicht

tools.detail: ANNIS (ANNotation of Information Structure), now in version 3.4.3, is an open source browser-based visualization architecture designed to annotate complex multilevel linguistic corpora. Now in its second version, ANNIS enables users to concurrently annotate, query and visualize data for syntax, semantics, morphology, prosody, referntiality, lexis and so forth. It also offers support for spoken language and audio and visual annotation.
tools.name: ANNIS (ANNotation of Information Structure)

tools.detail: TimeRime is a free, web-based timeline application for creating, viewing and comparing interactive timelines. This application requires registration, and timelines created within the application are public.
tools.name: TimeRime

tools.detail: Neatline is a free, open-source geotemporal exhibit-builder for creating complex maps and narrative sequences from collections of archives and artifacts. It is first and foremost a suite of plugins for the Omeka framework, but can also be accessed as a web-based sandbox independent of Omeka.
tools.name: Neatline

tools.detail: VisualEyes is web-based authoring tool for creating dynamic visualizations offered by the University of Virginia. It can be used to combine images, maps, charts, video and research data into a single visualization. It is comprehensively documented, including a reference guide to its XML structure and scripting, and to structuring data for inclusion.
tools.name: VisualEyes

tools.detail: LATtice is a free visualization tool for exploring and comparing texts across corpora. It also has features for 'drilling down' to determine what rhetorical categories make texts similar or different, and shows multiple visualizations in the same view. Documentation is available with download, and LATtice is available in Windows, OS X and Linux versions.
tools.name: LATtice

tools.detail: DocuScope is a text analysis environment first developed in 1998. It contains a suite of interactive visualization tools for corpus-based rhetorical analysis. At present, DocuScope is not available outside the originating research group. However, the Working Group for Digital Inquiry at the University of Wisconsin-Madison is currently working on a working environment that includes much of DocuScope's functions.
tools.name: DocuScope

tools.detail: CorpusSearch 2 is a free Java-based program for constructing syntactically annotated (parsed) corpora and searching them. Its functions include finding and counting lexical and syntactic patterns, correcting systemic errors and coding linguistic features.
tools.name: CorpusSearch 2

tools.detail: TAMS Analyzer is a tool designed to permit TAMS users to assign ethnographic codes to passages of text. It also has features for extracting, analyzing and saving the encoded information.
tools.name: TAMS Analyzer

tools.detail: TAToo (Text Analysis For Me Too) is a free, Flash-based widget affiliated with the TAPoR project. It is designed to be embedded into a web page, and can be run either from the user's own server or from the TAPoR server. The widget embeds TAPoR analytics into a web page, and can run analysis on text dragged and dropped into the provided field.
tools.name: TAToo (Text Analysis For Me Too)

tools.detail: PAIR (Pairwise Alignment for Intertextual Relations) is a free, open source sequence alignment algorithm for humanities text analysis. It identifies similar passages in a large corpus. Corpuses are indexed for future use, and incoming texts can be compared against the entire corpus.
tools.name: PAIR (Pairwise Alignment for Intertextual Relations)

tools.detail: The Google Ngram Viewer is a free, web-based tool affiliated with Google Books. It displays a graph showing how a set of user-supplied phrases have occurred in a corpus of books over a selection of years. The tool includes functions for part-of-speech tagging, ngram compositions and word dependencies, to name a few.
tools.name: Google Ngram Viewer

tools.detail: Concordle is a free, web based word cloud and concordance tool built in Javascript. It describes itself as the "not so pretty cousin of Wordle" and first debuted in 2006. Users can paste text into the provided box and generate a word cloud, concordance or list of words ordered by frequecy. It also includes a field for stop words.
tools.name: Concordle

tools.detail: HyperPo is an important legacy tool, developed as the first web-based text analysis tool aimed at humanities scholars available from 1996 through 2006. Users could input a web address, upload a file or directly enter text for analysis. HyperPo's interface was available in both English and French. Though no longer available for use, a capture of HyperPo can be viewed through the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine.
tools.name: HyperPo

tools.detail: PRORA was a historically important set of six interrelated programs for creating computerized concordances, first released in the 1960s. It output on punched cards, could be used for any language represented by the Latin alphabet, and also had functions for generating word lists and annotating texts. Glickman and Staalman desgined PRORA to reduce the requirement for researchers to learn computers to use them in their literary studies.
tools.name: PRORA

tools.detail: SCAN was a conversational programming language available in the 1970s for text analysis. It was specific to text processing and could be used divide a text into sentences or words or split on separators. It was capable of running counts on a text, printing particular sentences, checking whether a particular word has occured, matching word-patterns or finding alliterations.
tools.name: SCAN

tools.detail: CLAS (Computerized Language Analysis System) was an important historic text analysis system available in the 1970s. It was written in PL/I for IBM 360/370 punch card machines and performed standard statistical tests and concordances on natural language texts.
tools.name: CLAS (Computerized Language Analysis System)

tools.detail: SATO (Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur) is a longstanding historic text analysis system, now available as a free, web-based tool. Users can either draw off SATO's corpus or upload their own for analysis, and the texts for analysis may be in French, English or Spanish. It can perform standard text analysis functions such as word frequencies, comparisons, tokenizing and keyword in context, and has predefined filters for searches.
tools.name: SATO (Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur)

tools.detail: From the official BlackLab site: "BlackLab is a corpus retrieval engine built on top of Apache Lucene. It allows fast, complex searches with accurate hit highlighting on large, tagged and annotated, bodies of text. It was developed at the Institute of Dutch Lexicology (INL) to provide a fast and feature-rich search interface on our historical and contemporary text corpora. BlackLab is licensed under the Apache License 2.0." BlackLab is not an end-user application, but an extension to Apache Lucene.  It requires programming experience to use.  Several sites have so far been built using BlackLab.  The BlackLab FAQ at https://github.com/INL/BlackLab/wiki/Frequently-Asked-Questions lists several of these. BlackLab is very useful as search engine for morphologically adorned corpora.  The principal search language syntax is similar to that of traditional corpus search engine tools such as the Corpus Workbench or the Sketch Engine.
tools.name: INL BlackLab

tools.detail: The Chicago Homer is a multilingual database that uses the search and display capabilities of electronic texts to make the distinctive features of Early Greek epic accessible to readers with and without Greek. Except for fragments, it contains all the texts of these poems in the original Greek. In addition, the Chicago Homer includes English and German translations, in particular Lattimore's Iliad, James Huddleston's Odyssey, Daryl Hine's translations of Hesiod and the Homeric Hymns, and the German translations of the Iliad and Odyssey by Johan Heinrich Voss. Through the associated web site Eumaios users of the Chicago Homer can also from each line of the poem access pertinent Iliad Scholia and papyrus readings.
tools.name: The Chicago Homer

tools.detail: Word and Phrase is a free, web-based text analysis tool created by Dr. Mark Davies of Brigham Young University. Users can paste texts directly into the box provided. The tool provides a range of detailed information on a text's words and phrases, on one screen with a single search.
tools.name: Word and Phrase

tools.detail: NewRadial is an interactive visualization environment from the INKE team. It is designed to permit search, sorting and manipulation of database objects, commentary on connections and associations between database objects, and offer a place for large edition projects to create curated environments, browse them and encourage secondary scholarship on them. A web version is available with a number of databases for exploration, including the Canturbury Tales, Shakespeare quartos and selected novels and poetry.
tools.name: NewRadial (INKE)

tools.detail: TextGrid is a virtual research environment for text-based humanities scholarship. It offers a variety of tools and services for collaboratively creating, analyzing, editing and publishing texts. The TextGrid environment is split into two components, the Laboratory housing the tools and services, and the Repository for preserving reserach data and making it available to other scholars.
tools.name: TextGrid

tools.detail: Text Variation Explorer (TVE) is a Java tool for text visualization. TVE enables users to explore the effect of window size on a text's type-token ratio, proportion of hapax legomena and average word length; it can also cluster text fragments based on principal component analysis and has text comparison features. TVE is in beta and is presented 'as is'.
tools.name: Text Variation Explorer (TVE)

tools.detail: Pliny was a tool for working with annotations when conducting personal scholarly research, and can be used with both digital and print materials. It also had data manangement and organizational features, and was designed to facilitate reading, reacting to that reading and forming an interpretation. Pliny stored all data on the user's computer rather than remotely on the web.
tools.name: Pliny

tools.detail: Virtual Lightbox is a Java-base tool for comparing images online developed for the academic humanities, the library and museum community, and any users who use images as an important data type. It is available as both an application, which functions as a virual whiteboard and includes peer-to-peer, and an applet, which provides a flexible environment for image comparison. Virtual Lightbox was first developed in 2000, with version 2.0 of applet released in 2004.
tools.name: Virtual Lightbox

tools.detail: word2vec is a tool for computing vector representations of words for natural language processign and other related research. It generates a vocabulary from the user's text and learns a vector representation of its words.
tools.name: word2vec

tools.detail: BookLamp, part of the Book Genome Project, is a tool and a resource for finding books. It offers an alternative to social recommendation engines reliant on author popularity by treating its books as equal regardless of number of copies sold. BookLamp's goal is to match users to the books relevant to their interests as accurately as possible. Rather than genres, it uses 'StoryDNA', which identifies the thematic ingredients important to a book's narrative, in addition to how prominent that ingredient is within the text. BookLamp has been retired as of April 2014 and the website is no longer available. The site has been captured by the Internet Archive, and may still be viewed there via the Wayback Machine.
tools.name: BookLamp

tools.detail: BookLamp's Stream Graph Viewer is a tool for viewing where and how much of a story element ('StoryDNA') appears in a book. Books can be searched by title or author, and then graphed for one or several pieces of StoryDNA.
tools.name: BookLamp Labs: Stream Graph Viewer

tools.detail: BookLamp's StoryDNA Viewer is a corpus search tool designed to find all books sharing a user-selected set of characteristics ('StoryDNA'). From the resultant list, users can then view a book's entry in BookLamp to get more information about what characteristics it has, in what proportion, and in relation to other books in the database.
tools.name: BookLamp Labs: StoryDNA Viewer

tools.detail: BookLamp's Suggestion Viewer is a faceted search and browser tool for finding new books based on how similar they are to another book. Users can search by either title or author and select the book to center the search on. The Suggestion Viewer then generates a radial visualization of other books similar to the central book, showing the strength of the connection by the thickness of the connecting line and characteristic ('StoryDNA'). Users can switch between StoryDNA connections via drop list, and can click on an outer book to recenter the tool on that book. BookLamp and its tools have been retired as of April 2014 and the website is no longer available. The main site has been captured by the Internet Archive (https://web.archive.org/web/20140210212627/http://booklamp.org/) but this tool is not among the pages available there.
tools.name: BookLamp Labs: Suggestion Viewer

tools.detail: BookLamp's Sentiment Viewer is a visualization tool that graphs out a book's sentiments according to intensity and location in the text. Books to graph can be searched by title or author.
tools.name: BookLamp Labs: Sentiment Viewer

tools.detail: Weka (Waikato Environment for Knowledge Analysis) is a free Java-based data mining workbench of machine learning algorithms, offered by the Machine Learning Group of the University of Waikato. It includes tools for data pre-processing, classification, clustering and visualization, among others. Development on Weka began in the early 1990s and it is extensively documented.
tools.name: Weka (Waikato Environment for Knowledge Analysis)

tools.detail: Textometrica is a free, web based text analysis tool offered by HUMlab at Umeå University. Users can upload a plain-text file and examine its word frequencies, see co-occurrences, and generate visualizations and graphs.
tools.name: Textometrica

tools.detail: Welkin is a free tool for visualizing complex RDF models offered for download by the SIMILE Project. Rather than permitting users to focus on specific nodes, it provides analytical views such as an overview of a dataset's connectivity or potential mappings between resources and ontologies. It runs best through Java WebStart and is compatible with Windows, OS X and Linux.
tools.name: SIMILE Widgets: Welkin

tools.detail: LodLive is a web-based tool developed to demonstrate Linked Data standards applied to browsing RDF resources with a simple interface. Users can search preset datasets, including DBpedia and Freebase, or search a resource available at a web address of the user's choice. LodLive is also available for download.
tools.name: LodLive

tools.detail: Tom Sawyer Perspectives is a commercial software package for data visualization and analysis. It provides a graphical software development kit and preview environment, including layout and Tom Sawyer Software's proprietary data visualization reference architecture. The SDK is particularly aimed at developers seeking to create data-oriented visualization applications, and permits users to customize with toolbars, context menus, and editing behaviour, to name a few. Applications are designed to enable design sharing and reuse, including via web application deployment. The Java version of Tom Sawyer Perspectives is available for Windows, OS X and Linux environments, and .NET for Windows only. Evaluation copies are available on request; no prices are quoted on the site.
tools.name: Tom Sawyer Perspectives

tools.detail: TextDNA is a free tool for large-scale overview analysis of linguistic data offered by the University of Wisconsin, Madison. It identifies patterns within a text, and enables users to compare ordered sets of data with its sequence visualization. It can be used with texts stored in databases, Google N-Grams datasets and CSV files.
tools.name: TextDNA

tools.detail: Prefuse is a Java framework for creating interactive information visualization applications from the University of California at Berkeley's Visualization Lab. It can be used to design standalone applications, visual components within other applications and web applets.
tools.name: Prefuse

tools.detail: OntoViz is a tab widget included in the Protégé software package for visualizing Protégé ontologies in conjunction with GraphViz. It allows developers to manage and configure visualizations according to their needs.
tools.name: OntoViz

tools.detail: The NeOn Toolkit is an open source environment for engineering ontologies. It supports both the F-logic and OWL ontologies, and its functions include annotation, documentation, ontology evaluation and matching and human-ontology interaction.
tools.name: NeOn Toolkit

tools.detail: RDF Gravity (RDF Graph Visualization Tool) is a free, open-source visualization tool from Salzburg Research's Knowledge Information Systems Group. It supports RDF graph structures and OWL ontologies, including multiple RDF files, and offers a variety of filters for its visualizations.
tools.name: RDF Gravity

tools.detail: Visual Browser is a Java application for visualizing RDF data using the Jena framework. The resultant graphs are animated and permit users to expand and hide nodes and switch the view of edges, allowing them to focus on a small part of the network. The visualization engine is derived from TouchGraph LLC and follows the navigation approach of WebOFDAV, a system based on the concept of exploratory navigation to reduce chances of getting “lost in hyperspace” situation.
tools.name: Visual Browser

tools.detail: RDF2SVG is a web-based tool from the Rhizomik initiative for transforming RDF/XML data into an SVG representation. It can also accept N-triples and N3 input, and includes a feature for filtering the user's defined preferred language from the source data.
tools.name: RDF2SVG (Rhizomik)

tools.detail: RelFinder is an RDF relationship discovery tool developed as part of the Visual Data Web toolset and based on the Adobe Flex open source framework. It is designed to provide an overview of RDF data through interactive visualization and exporation. Features include highlighting and filtering, and the tool permits both global and detail views. It is optimized for RDF data that provided standard SPARQL access.
tools.name: RelFinder

tools.detail: The W3C RDF Validation Service is a free, web-based tool for checking RDF documents for errors and displaying the results. It can display in triples, a graph, or a combination of the two, and can format the graph in a variety of file formats including PNG, SVG and GIF. Documents can be pasted directly into the provided form or from a provided URI.
tools.name: W3C RDF Validation Service

tools.detail: Google Charts (formerly the Google Visualization API) is a web-based interface for interactive data visualization via HTML5 and SVG. It includes a number of preset chart types ranging from line charts to word trees and all are customizable. A separate selection of user community contributed chart types is also available. Within a chart, the API identifies events that users can trigger with presets ranging from simple clicks to Javascript methods, and enable users to construct chart dashboards that can be embedded in their website along with the chart proper.
tools.name: Google Charts

tools.detail: Wiki Map Project was designed by Protovis and jQuery to visualize the data provided by Wikipedia. The program provides data animation and graph visualization with an option to explore the nodes connections.
tools.name: Wiki Map Project

tools.detail: interHist is a free visualization prototype offered by EURAC and implemented in JavaScript using the D3.js library. It enables users to interactively explore concordances from search queries and can accomodate large result sets in its display.
tools.name: EURAC: interHist

tools.detail: The Extended Linguistic Dependency Diagrams (xLDDs) is a visualization software package offered by EURAC and implemented in JavaScript using the Protovis tookit. The xLDDs shows dependency structures with dynamic interaction in its visualizations, and can accomodate various types of linguistic information.
tools.name: EURAC: Extended Linguistic Dependency Diagrams (xLDDs)

tools.detail: Structured Parallel Coordinates is a free JavaScript data visualization tool offered by EURAC. It is intended for data that contains some kind of structure, such as temporal ordering, strings or ranked orderings. EURAC has provided several examples, such as ngram comparisons, (sub)corpus comparison and KWIC with live corpus queries.
tools.name: EURAC: Structured Parallel Coordinates

tools.detail: SplitsTree4 is a free Java tool for generating phylogenic (similarity) networks from Universitat Tubingen. While designed for molecular sequence data, it can also visualize humanities data such as document sequence alignments.
tools.name: SplitsTree4

tools.detail: The CMU-Cambridge Statistical Language Modelling Toolkit is a longstanding set of Unix tools offered by Carnegie Mellon University and Cambridge University. It includes functions for word frequency, n-grams, vocabulary and words marked as 'context cues'. Version 1 was written by Roni Rosenfel and released in 1994.
tools.name: CMU-Cambridge Statistical Language Modelling Toolkit

tools.detail: Automatic Mapping Among Lexico-Grammatical Annotation Models (AMALGAM) is a free, longstanding tool for tagging text according to part of speech (PoS) from Leeds University. It includes eight PoS tag schemes, and a Multi-Tagged Corpus of samples tagged with various schemas.
tools.name: Automatic Mapping Among Lexico-Grammatical Annotation Models (AMALGAM)

tools.detail: TnT, which is short for Trigrams'n'Tags, is a statistical part-of-speech tagger from Universitat de Saarlandes. It can be trained on a variety of corpora and languages, and is based on the Viterbi algorithm for second order Markov models. It includes language models for English and German. This program is only available on request.
tools.name: TnT (Trigrams'n'Tags)

tools.detail: YAGO is a semantic knowledge base of over 10 million entities, and over 120 million facts about those entities, developed by the Max Planck Institut Informatik. Its base derives from Wikipedia, WordNet and GeoNames, and the accuaracy has not only been manually evaluated, but relations are also provided with an annotation stating its confidence value. The YAGO ontology includes spacial and temporal dimensions, and integrates WordNet's thematic domains as well. It can be queried or browsed right from the website, and the full ontology is available for download.
tools.name: YAGO

tools.detail: Tableau Public is a free data visualization tool aimed at online publishers and academics. It can be used to create an interactive visualization, and also enables users to publish it to the web as an embed or share it via a link. Users must download the desktop interface, and all projects created through the system are saved remotely to the Tableau Public server rather than to the user's local machine. It is availabe for both Windows and OS X, and has a visual interface with a simple drag and drop process.
tools.name: Tableau Public

tools.detail: IsaViz is a visual authoring and data browsing tool for RDF models represented as graphs, developed by the W3C. permits uses to both create and edit graphs, and can render graphs from GSS stylesheets as a node-link diagram. It is freely available for download. This tool is no longer in active development.
tools.name: IsaViz

tools.detail: ProcessingJS is an open source visual programming language for the work with data visualization, electronic arts and visual design communities. It operates under the web standards and doesn’t require any plug-ins. The tool promotes visual esthetics of computer programming on the web. ProcessingJS is a sister project to Processing.
tools.name: ProcessingJS

tools.detail: Pajek is a free tool for large network analysis and visualization in continuous development since 1996. It can handle large datasets from diverse sources, such as collaboration networks, citiation networks, data mining, and Internet-derived networks. Pajek is only available for Windows, and was implemented in Delphi (Pascal).
tools.name: Pajek

tools.detail: The UMDHMM: Hidden Markov Model Toolkit is a free UNIX implementation of hidden Markov models useful for speech recognition from Tapas Kanungo. It includes implementations of the Forward-Backward, Viterbi and Baum-Welch algorithms.
tools.name: UMDHMM: Hidden Markov Model Toolkit

tools.detail: The Apple Pie Parser is a free tool from the 1990s for generating a grammar from a syntactially tagged corpus offered by the Department of Computer Science at New York University. It generates a syntactic tree like those of the Penn Tree Bank, and is still available for download.
tools.name: Apple Pie Parser

tools.detail: The Ngram Statistics Package (NSP) is a free suite for identifying word and character ngrams in large corpora developed by Ted Pederson and his team. It also generates frequency data and co-occurrences, and can generate correlations between two files. It has been in continuous development since the 1990s and has been used in developing the SenseCluster and Senseval tools.
tools.name: Ngram Statistics Package (NSP)

tools.detail: TATOO (ISSCO Tagger Tool) is a free, trainable text part-of-speech tagger based on hidden Markov models offered by the ISSCO in Geneva. It was developed in the 1990s and is still available for download.
tools.name: TATOO (ISSCO Tagger Tool)

tools.detail: The UVic Image Markup Tool is a free tool for annotating images and storing the annotations in XML files from the University of Victoria's Humanities Computing and Media Centre. Its interface is designed for users without prior XML experience with additional functions for users familiar with XML, and supports multiple languages. The Image Markup Tool is available for Windows, and will also run in Linux with Wine.
tools.name: UVic Image Markup Tool

tools.detail: JEUDEMO was an information retrieval program developed at the University of Montreal in the 1970s. It built on and extended the functionality of COCOA by including Boolean search functions to search for patterns within a text such as co-occurences, but saw limited adoption as it required texts to be supplied on punched cards or paper tape and was programmed in a language exclusive to the CDC Cyber 74 computer system.
tools.name: JEUDEMO

tools.detail: RATS (Random-Accessible Text Systems) was a PL/I utility for text analysis developed by John B. Smith of Pennsylvania State Univeristy in the early 1970s. It was aimed at researchers with some experience with programming and aimed to streamline the text analysis process while permitting users to customize the program to suit their work. As a system, Smith promoted RATS for concordences, thematic distributions and transitional matrixes.
tools.name: RATS (Random-Accessible Text Systems)

tools.detail: etcML (Easy Text Classification with Machine Learning) is a free text analysis tool from Stanford University that uses machine learning to identify positive and negative sentiments in texts. Users can analyze their own dataset, use a dataset provided with the tool, or search Twitter for keywords of interest.
tools.name: etcML

tools.detail: LitStats is a tool for statistical analysis of natural language texts developed in the 1980s by Dr. Stephen Reimer of the University of Alberta. From an ASCII text, it can generate word frequency counts, word lengths, initial letter frequencies, sentence length frequencies and verbal segment frequencies. It was originally developed for an IBM 3033, and can still be run on systems using Windows XP.
tools.name: LitStats

tools.detail: BIBCON was a key-word-out-of-context system for concordances developed in FORTRAN and available in the 1960s.  It was a modified version of another system, KWIC.
tools.name: BIBCON

tools.detail: KWIC was an indexing and concordance tool available in the 1960s. Contrary to its name, KWIC functioned as a 'key-word-out-of-context' tool.
tools.name: KWIC

tools.detail: The CETA (Centre pour l'Etude de la Traduction Automatique) Parser was a program developed in the 1960s that could automatically reduce Russian sentences to a string of words and provide equivalents for each in French. CETA developed its parser in conjunction with Professor Mel'chuk of Moscow.
tools.name: CETA Parser

tools.detail: The MITRE Syntactic Analysis Procedure was a program developed in the 1960s for analyzing English phrase structures.
tools.name: MITRE Syntactic Analysis Procedure

tools.detail: The Berkeley Parser was a program for parsing English sentences developed at the University of California at Berkeley and available in the 1960s
tools.name: Berkeley Parser

tools.detail: The Harvard Predictive Analyser was a program for analyzing and generating English sentences from Harvard University in the 1960s.
tools.name: Harvard Predictive Analyser

tools.detail: STAP (State Transition Network Analysis Procedure) was a program for parsing developed in the 1960s. It could determine correct parsing by following all possible branches until all possibilities permitted by its ruleset were exhausted.
tools.name: STAP

tools.detail: TEXTAN was a program developed by Suzanne Hanon of the University of Aarhus in the 1970s for locating English loan words in French texts. It was written in ALGOL 4 and consisted of two programs. TEXTAN 1 learned anglicisms developed manually from French newspapers, while TEXTAN 2 searched a French text and located anglicisms.
tools.name: TEXTAN

tools.detail: T.A.P (Text Analysis Program) was a program for literary analysis developed in the 1970s at Emory University. It could also generate concordances and word-frequency lists, measure types and tokens, and show collocates for key words defined by the user. T.A.P. was developed in Assembly Language for Emory's UNIVAC Spectra 70/17.
tools.name: T.A.P (Text Analysis Program)

tools.detail: UNICORN was a concording system developed in the 1970s. It was developed in FORTRAN IV to replace more restricted programs at at the University of Colorado at Boulder, and could process most machine-readable texts.
tools.name: UNICORN

tools.detail: AUTHOR was a set of interrelated programs for determining authorship developed in the 1970s at Pennsylvania State University. The system was developed in PL/I and was available for the IBM 370. It integrated RATS for word extraction, and MINITAB II for statistics.
tools.name: AUTHOR

tools.detail: HAWKEYE was a program for text analysis for the IBM 370 and developed in the 1970s. It could accept text from an IBM typewriter and had functions to describe text componants such as words and clause lengths, conduct frequency analyses, and generate word-class distributions. HAWKEYE was written in PL/I as an updated and improved verison of EYEBALL.
tools.name: HAWKEYE

tools.detail: LEMMA was a program package for lemmatizing German word-forms released in 1978. It was designed to work with computer-readable corpora. The algorithm was implemented in PL/I on an IBM 370/168 computer.
tools.name: LEMMA

tools.detail: UNICON was a concordance generator written in FORTRAN IV and available in the 1960s. It was available first for the IBM 7094, and for IBM 1410/7090 computers after 1970.
tools.name: UNICON

tools.detail: DISCON was concordance program available in the 1960s designed to handle bilingual texts.
tools.name: DISCON

tools.detail: TRICON was a concordance program developed in the 1960s for the Berkeley Machine Translation Project. The program was designed to work with texts in languages written in non-Roman alphabets, such as Russian (original version) or Judeo Arabic texts (as of 1967). It was developed in FORTRAN G and ran on IBM 360/70 computers.
tools.name: TRICON

tools.detail: The Scharfenberg-Smith Concordance Program, briefly known as the ICRH (Institute for Computer Research in the Humanities) Concordance Generator, was developed at the Thomas J. Watson Reserach Centre as part of research in machine translation from Russian to English. It was first described in 1964 as a program for teh IBM 7090.
tools.name: Scharfenberg-Smith Concordance Program

tools.detail: WATCON was a program used extensively at the University of Waterloo for humanities research in the 1970s. It was developed by Philip H. Smith Jr. and WATCHUM (Waterloo Computing in the Humanities) as a text-handling package with concordance applications, and can be regarded as a descendent of the Scharfenberg-Smith Concordance Program.
tools.name: WATCON

tools.detail: CONCORD was a concordance program developed in 1968 to identify and sort collocating words or phrases. Notably, it allowed users to sort words ending in one of several suffixes (such as -er or -est) to be grouped together.
tools.name: CONCORD

tools.detail: AUTOSTYL was a set of linked programs for stylistic analysis developed by Louis T. Milic in the 1980s. Its functions included frequency distributions for letters in words, syllable countering, affix analysis, indexing, and word classification.
tools.name: AUTOSTYL

tools.detail: SALEM was a system for natural language processing developed in the 1970s. It was written in standard FORTRAN, and automated lemmatization of German texts. Its main component was a program known as SATAN (Saarbrucker Automatische Text-analyse).
tools.name: SALEM

tools.detail: BALCON (Bilingual Analytical Literary and Linguistic Concordance) was a tool for creating bilingual concordances available in the 1970s.
tools.name: BALCON (Bilingual Analytical Literary and Linguistic Concordance)

tools.detail: The CRIC-8 CONCORDER (Cross-Reference in Context) was a tool for creating a 'master' concordance of a text available in the 1970s.
tools.name: CRIC-8 CONCORDER (Cross-Reference in Context)

tools.detail: TEXTCORD is a concordance program available in the 1980s. It was developed in SPITBOL at the University of Toronto's Divinity School.
tools.name: TEXTCORD

tools.detail: COGS-3 was a general-purpose concordance program for IBM and DEC mainframe computers at the University of Toronto. It was developed in the 1980s in PL/I and also included a lemmatization feature.
tools.name: COGS-3

tools.detail: The Oxford Concordance Program (OCP) was a major and influential early concordance program developed in the late 1970s and early 1980s at the Oxford University Computing Service. It was influnced by CLOC and COCOA, and aimed to be more user-friendly than its predecessors.
tools.name: Oxford Concordance Program (OCP)

tools.detail: DEREDEC was a programming system and workbench for linguistics and text analysis written in LISP in the 1980s. It enabled syntactic and texual parsing, and could link phrases by their contenxual dependency relations.
tools.name: DEREDEC

tools.detail: DISCAN was a tool for content and discourse analysis originally available for mainframe computers, and adapted for PCs with DOS 3.0 in 1991. It accepted ASCII files, could create KWIC and co-occurrence listings, and had modules for both creating content analysis dictionaries and performing content analysis.
tools.name: DISCAN

tools.detail: STRAP 2.0 (Structural Analysis Programs) was a package of interrelated programs for analyzing tagged texts. It was intended to index, conduct contextual searches and generate distribution diagrams for literary texts. It could also recognize punctuation marks, generate word counts, and accommodate alphabets for multiple languages.
tools.name: STRAP 2.0

tools.detail: FUNES was an NLP system for analyzing short newspaper stories. It was written in Prolog and conducted syntactic parsing and semantic analysis on a text to create a case-based semantic representation.
tools.name: FUNES

tools.detail: VOCAB - U - LISTER was a tool for lemmatizing texts developed at the University of Toronto in the 1990s. It could handle Spanish text and could process as many as 2000 words at a time.
tools.name: VOCAB - U - LISTER

tools.detail: SimCA 2.0 was a program for correspondence analysis that could generate coordinates in seven dimensions for each data point.
tools.name: SimCA 2.0

tools.detail: ABFREQ was a tool for identifying key words within a text developed in the 1980s. It identified key words by comparing thier frequency within the user's text to the frequency of the same words in a control corpus.
tools.name: ABFREQ

tools.detail: PANVS was a system for syntactic analysis of Arabic text developed in the 1990s. It was written in TURBO PROLOG for IBM PS/2 computers, and included lexical and morphological analyzers, a parser, and a module for automatic spelling correction.
tools.name: PANVS

tools.detail: GERTWOL is a tool for the morphological analysis of German texts. A limited version for analyzing single words is now available for free through the developer's website.
tools.name: GERTWOL

tools.detail: Textable is a an add-on tool developed for the Orange data mining and visualization package. Its functions include the ability to build data tables from textual data, to import data from other sources, and to build concordances and collocations. It also enables users to segment and annotate text, systematically recode data, determine subsets, and compute frequency and complexity measures.
tools.name: Textable

tools.detail: TOSCA was a syntactic analysis system available in the 1990s. It required users to apply word class tags and syntactic markers, which it then used for syntactic parsing.
tools.name: TOSCA

tools.detail: SUSS (Sunderland University SENSEVAL System) was an algorithm for word sense disambiguation developed for the inaugural SENSEVAL event in 1998.
tools.name: SUSS (Sunderland University SENSEVAL System)

tools.detail: grling-sdm (graphical models for linguistic applications - supervised decomposable model search) was a system for assigning probabilistic classification to words developed for the 1998 SENSEVAL competition for word-sense disambiguation. Its selection approach also had applications to related natural language processing problems.
tools.name: grling-sdm

tools.detail: Wisdom was a word sense disambiguation system that participated in the 1998 SENSEVAL competition. It used a simple supervised learning algorithm, drawing on co-occurrence statistics.
tools.name: Wisdom

tools.detail: SCBD (Sentence and Chunk Boundaries Detector) was an NLP tool suited to Modern Greek text. It could detect sentence and chunk boundaries within an unrestricted text, could assign style markers, and was effective even on a large corpus of 200,000 words
tools.name: SCBD (Sentence and Chunk Boundaries Detector)

tools.detail: EXPLEX (EXtracting information about Proper nouns to provide LEXical information) was a natural language processing system available in the 1990s. It was developed to create lexical entries for nouns appearing in the Wall Street Journal.
tools.name: EXPLEX

tools.detail: IITagger was a part of speech tagging system developed in the 1990s to assign part of speech information to words from the Wall Street Journal.
tools.name: IITagger

tools.detail: WinBrill is a part-of-speech tagger developed by Eric Brill in the 1990s for the French language laboratory ATILF. It was originally available for UNIX, with WinBrill optimized for Windows 95/98/NT as of 1999. The ATILP provided a vocabulary and rules files based on FRANTEXT data. Versions of the Brill tagger are still extant online.
tools.name: WinBrill

tools.detail: SRILM (SRI Language Modelling Toolkit) is a toolkit for language modelling first developed in the 1990s and still in active development. It has applications in speech recognition, statistical tagging, segmentation and machine translation. The toolkit is available for Windows and UNIX, and users have developed a variety of extensions for it.
tools.name: SRILM (SRI Language Modelling Toolkit)

tools.detail: KH Coder is a tool for quantitative content analysis and text mining that has been under continuous development since 2001. It was originally developed for Japanese text and now supports numerous other languages, including English, Italian and French. KH Coder also has computational linguistics applications.
tools.name: KH Coder

tools.detail: RQDA is a free R package for qualitative analysis, developed specifically to analyze textual data. It is available for Windows, Linux/FreeBSD and Mac OS X. It currently requires texts to be in plain text format. RQDA supports non-English texts, and has been tested with Simplified Chinese in particular.
tools.name: RQDA

tools.detail: Annotation Studio is an open source, web-based annotation application that integrates a powerful set of textual interpretation tools behind an intuitive and easy-to-use interface. Users can upload their own texts, and annotate with styled text, video, images, and weblinks. To date, the project has been used with great success in disciplines such as Writing, Literature, Foreign Languages, Anthropology, Film and Media Studies, and others at institutions including Harvard, Yale, Stanford, MIT, Barnard College, and Washington University.
tools.name: Annotation Studio

tools.detail: Paper Machines is a topic modelling and visualization tool available as a plugin for Zotero. It analyzes Zotero bibliographic collections based on a selection of text mining processes, and enables users to export a variety of visualizations, such as word clouds, phrase nets or heat maps, from the results.
tools.name: Paper Machines

tools.detail:
Overview is a free, web-based tool for document mining. Developed by and for journalists, Overview is also broadly applicable to other corpus-based research applications. Aside from providing advanced search features such as regular expressions and fuzzy matching, Overview automatically sorts documents according to topic and provides a fast visualization and reading interface. You can apply tags to search results, individual documents, or entire topics to track what you've found, then export the entire document set with its tags to perform further processing or create visualization.
