It’s been used for qualitative research, social media conversation analysis, legal document review, digital humanities, and more.    
Overview can be run via the web interface (max 200 000 documents) or downloaded and installed. The system can import documents in PDF or CSV format and currently supports analysis in 9 languages. The code is open source and there is a plugin API to extend Overview's analysis and visualization capability.
tools.name: Overview

tools.detail: RAW is a free, open-source web application for creating visualizations that can be exported in SVG or PNG format and embedded into a website. Users can upload data with RAW's web interface and generate a variety of vector-based visualizations. RAW uses the D3.js library, and is maintained by the Density Design research studio at Polaitecnico di Milano.
tools.name: RAW

tools.detail: SentiStrength is a tool for sentiment analysis available for free to academic users (with registration), in Java and Windows-optimized versions. It estimates the strength of sentiment in short texts, and can handle informal language. Strength is expressed in a scale of 1 to 5 for positive sentiments, and -1 to -5 for negative; it also includes an option for assessing neutrality. SentiStrength is available for multiple languages, with extensibility for languages and contexts not already included. According to the developers, SentiStrength has human-level accuracy for short English texts. Commercial users must purchase a license.
tools.name: SentiStrength

tools.detail: Compare Lists is a free, web-based tool for comparing text from two lists of URLs supplied by the user. This tool was developed and is maintained by the Digital Methods Initiative.
tools.name: Compare Lists

tools.detail: The Google Blogsearch Scraper is a free, web-based tool for batch querying Google Blog Search. Users can submit a list of URLs to search, and a set of keywords to apply to them. For each query, the tool supplies a tag cloud and an HTML table, plus a text file that may be downloaded for further analysis.
tools.name: Google Blogsearch Scraper

tools.detail: Netvizz is a free, web-based tool for extracting datasets from Facebook. As the tool utilizes Facebook Apps, users must have a Facebook account to access it.
tools.name: Netvizz

tools.detail: NetvizzToSentiStrength is a free, web-based sentiment analysis tool for short texts, designed to work particularly with a Netvizz search of Facebook data. In addition to Netvizz data, it also accepts DMI-TCAT and CSV files.
tools.name: NetvizzToSentiStrength

tools.detail: Google News Scraper is a free, web-based tool for batch querying news.google.com. Users can specify search terms, news sources, date range, location, language, version of Google (ex. .com, .ca, .co.uk, etc.), and what facets to include in the output. The tool returns the results as a table suitable for further analysis, and can also include thumbnail images for each search item.
tools.name: Google News Scraper

tools.detail: Googlescraper (Lippmannian Device) is a free, web-based tool for querying Google and saving the results for analysis. It allow users to specify URLs, keywords, and which keywords apply to each URL. The tool outputs as HTML, a tag cloud, and a text file. The tool must be used with FireFox, and requires users to first install the DMI toolbar, which permits the tool to work around Google's block against automated requests.
tools.name: Googlescraper (Lippmannian Device)

tools.detail: Issuecrawler is a free, web-based tool for performing co-link analysis on URLs, and generating a cluster graph of the results. Its options include snowball crawling for up to three degrees of separation, and inter-actor crawling. Users must request a free account before using the tool.
tools.name: Issuecrawler

tools.detail: Compare Networks Over Time is a free, web-based tool for comparing Issuecrawler networks, or data from a regularly scheduled crawl. The tool displays ranked actor lists for each comparison, in a format suitable for graphing via spreadsheet software. Tool input must be in XML format. Compare Networks Over Time is designed to be used particularly with output from the Govcom Foundation's Issuecrawler tool.
tools.name: Compare Networks Over Time

tools.detail: The Ranked Deep Pages from Core Issue Crawler Network is a free, web-based tool for ranking pages based on inlink counts from a user-supplied Issuecrawler XML file. It outputs a three-column table with numbers, the inlink count from the core network, and the inlink count from the periphery of the network.
tools.name: Ranked Deep Pages from Core Issue Crawler Network

tools.detail: Issue Discovery is a tool for extracting the most prominent words and phrases from user-supplied URLs, texts or Issuecrawler XML result files. It is designed as a heuristic for data exploration rather than as an empirical tool.
tools.name: Issue Discovery

tools.detail: The Lippmannian Device to Gephi is a free, web-based tool for converting the output of the Digital Methods Association's Googlescraper (Lippmannian Device) tool to a format suitable for Gephi visualization. From a Googlescraper file, it generates a GEXF file with defined nodes and weighted edges based on the queries and URLs in the original file. Once loaded into Gephi, the nodes can be resized to emphasize the most important query/URL combinations.
tools.name: Lippmannian Device to Gephi

tools.detail: Open Calais Issue Discovery is a free, open source tool for textual analysis. From a text file, URLs or an Issuecrawler XML file, it generates a ranked table of terms and an overall count corresponding to the most relevant words and phrases in the source text or issue network.
tools.name: Open Calais Issue Discovery

tools.detail: Twitter Capture and Analysis Toolset (DMI-TCAT) is a free, open source tool for capturing and analyzing tweets. The tool's web interface is currently closed to researchers outside the University of Amsterdam's Media Studies department, however, the source code is available for download and installation via Github.
tools.name: Twitter Capture and Analysis Toolset (DMI-TCAT)

tools.detail: Netlytic is a free, web-based tool for analyzing and visualizing text and social network data. It enables users to capture data from sources such as social media, blogs or online forums; identify themes and actors; and generate both chain and personal name networks for further analysis and visualization. Users can import datasets from RSS, cloud storage (Google Drive or Dropbox), Twitter, YouTube, Instagram and a plain text file. Results can be exported in formats accessible to other network analysis tools, such as CSV.
tools.name: Netlytic

tools.detail: TAGS (Twitter Archiving Google Spreadsheet) v5.1 is a tool for automatically pulling Twitter search results into a Google spreadsheet for further analysis. Users can set TAGS 5.1 to update the resulting archive hourly or at a frequency of their specification, and includes options for filtering out spam, result pagination, and setting an upper limit on tweets collected (to a maximum of 18000).
tools.name: TAGS (Twitter Archiving Google Spreadsheet) v5.1

tools.detail: Poem Viewer is a free, web based experimental tool for exploring, analyzing and visualizing poetry based on linguistic characteristics, for use as a supplement to close reading. Users can choose from a list of pre-loaded poems, or paste a poem of their choosing into the provided text box.
tools.name: Poem Viewer

tools.detail: The Macro-Etymological Analyzer is a free, open-source tool for etymological analysis of plain-text documents. Users can upload their own file, or choose from a list of pre-loaded texts. The tool conducts a frequency analysis and then identifies the language families represented in the text from the list of unique words. It outputs a chart showing the percentage of words belonging to each language family identified, a full list of words with those not in the dictionary clearly marked, and a table outputting the full freqency analysis results.
tools.name: Macro-Etymological Analyzer

tools.detail: Prospéro (PROgramme de Sociologie Pragmatique, Expérimentale et Réflexive sur Ordinateur) is a free text analysis tool aimed at scholars in the Humanities capable of complex analysis on natural language. It permits users to classify and track records or thematic sets within a text or corpus for the purpose of exploration, analysis and comparison. It identifies places in a text that display uncertainty, controversy, criticism, and enables the user to establish rule and meta-rules to separate factual statements from views and interpretations. Prospéro is particularly designed for complex cases composed of large texts containing heterogenous discourse.
tools.name: Prospéro (PROgramme de Sociologie Pragmatique, Expérimentale et Réflexive sur Ordinateur)

tools.detail: The Stanford NLP Group's Sentiment Analysis tool is a free, web based live demo based on a sentiment analysis treebank, trained to predict the sentiment in movie reviews. Users can test out the sentiment analysis model with their own text in the box provided. The dataset and code is available for download, and the sentiment analysis model is now integrated into Stanford CoreNLP.
tools.name: Stanford Sentiment Analysis

tools.detail: twXplorer is a free, web-based tool for querying Twitter and exploring the search results based on common words, hashtags and commonly shared links. Each search brings up the 500 most recent tweets for that search term, and the tool permits users to save 'snapshots' for later analysis. twXplorer requires users to log in with their Twitter account.
tools.name: twXplorer

tools.detail: wordsimilarity (Word 2 Word) is a free, open source tool for plotting and visualizing semantic spaces within a corpus. The tool's visualizations assign words to nodes, with similarities marked by edges between nodes of varying strength. The visualizations are designed to be easy to manipulate based on graph data, and the system includes a library of ready-to-use relationship models with an interface for training the models based on a variety of language sources.
tools.name: wordsimilarity (Word 2 Word)

tools.detail: word tree is a free, web-based tool for generating dynamic word trees from user-supplied texts. Users can paste their text directly in the box provided, enter a URL or Twitter handle in the search bar, or install the bookmarklet into their browser's bookmarks bar to run the tool on their current page. Within the visualization, users can generate trees for any keyword based on search or from a click in the interface, and can reverse the direction of the tree (forward or back from the keyword within the text).
tools.name: word tree

tools.detail: WordWanderer is a free, web-based tool for visualizing and exploring text. It combines search, concordance and word cloud attributes to enable users to explore their texts. Users can paste their own texts into the box provided, or choose from a list of preloaded texts. It includes the ability to include or hide words based on parts of speech, a stop list or a user-provided list, and can display the text based on relative frequency, context or comparison. To view specific words, users can search them or click on them in the visualization.
tools.name: WordWanderer

tools.detail: Version Variation Visualization is an interrelated set of free, usable prototypes for visualizing and exploring culturally important works in relation to their world-wide translations. It allows users to explore either the inlcuded corpora or their own texts via time-maps, alignment maps, parallel views or a concordance view accommodating multiple translations in the same viewer. Version Variation Visualization is particularly valuable for its focus on translation and re-translation of text, and its capacity to accommodate and show multiple version of the same text or passage.
tools.name: Version Variation Visualization

tools.detail: The DfR Browser is a free, open source visualization interface for exploring aggragates of articles from the JSTOR database. It uses topic modelling, co-occurrances and document metadata to provide multiple views on the corpus of interest based on topic searches, via several specialized views such as scaled, list and yearly subviews. Users can test the DfR browser via the provided web demo, which incudes a broad selection of pre-loaded topics, or download the source code to use the tool with their own data. The tool's output can be imported into Mallet for further analysis.
tools.name: DfR Browser

tools.detail: jsLDA is a free, open source tool for corpus-based in browser topic modelling. Users can test the tool via the provided demo, or download the source code to run on their own system. Users can load any corpus accessible from a URL, and can train the tool on the topics within the corpus via the iteration function. Once jsLDA has been trained to the user's satisfaction, documents can be sorted according to topic and explored based on topic correlations.
tools.name: jsLDA

tools.detail: The Networked Corpus is a free, open source tool for navigating a corpus of plain text files via topic modelling using MALLET. The tool consistes of a Python script, and generates a collection of HTML files that can be explored further via the user's web browser. To use The Networked Corpus, users must have a minimum of Python 2.7.x, NumPy, SciPy and MALLET 2.0.7 installed on their system.
tools.name: The Networked Corpus

tools.detail: Topic Modelling Tool is a free, open source tool for Latent Dirichlet Allocation topic modelling with a graphical user interface. The tool learns topics in a user-supplied corpus of plain text files, and outputs results as a CSV file for further analysis.
tools.name: Topic Modelling Tool

tools.detail: NodeXL is a free, open source tool for generating and exploring network graphs from Microsoft Excel files. It is particularly suited to data from social media sources, and includes the ability to directly import data from Twitter, YouTube, Flickr and email, with additional plugins available for gathering data from Facebook, Microsoft Exchange, wikis and URLs. The tool generates visualizations that can be adjusted, zoomed and filtered, with additional features for vertex grouping, graphing metric calculations, and automating tasks. NodeXL can both import and export data in GraphML, Pajek, UCINet and matrix formats.
tools.name: NodeXL

tools.detail: SNOBOL is a programming language developed in the 1960s capable of symbol and free-form string manipulation that was of particular value to early computer-based Humanities research. SNOBOL4 was the final version released by AT&T Bell Laboratories.
tools.name: SNOBOL (String Oriented Symbolic Language)

tools.detail: FORTRAN (from 'formula translating system') was a major programming language first developed by IBM in the late 1950s. While originally intended for science and engineering, with substantial drawbacks for users seeking to conduct text processing, its wide availability in academic computing centres neverthless made it an attractive choice for Humanities scholars seeking to automate research processes.
tools.name: FORTRAN

tools.detail: COMIT was an early string processing programming language developed for IBM 700/7000 computers at MIT from the late 1950s to mid 1960s. It was particularly designed for linguistics and natural language processing, and was taught to humanists to aid their research in the 1960s.
tools.name: COMIT

tools.detail: COBOL (Common Business-Oriented Language) is a programming language first developed for business applications in the late 1950s. It was frequently referenced by humanists interested in applying computers and algorithms to their research, though infrequently used.
tools.name: COBOL

tools.detail: ALGOL (Algorithmic Language) was a programming language developed in the mid 1950s and often discussed in relation to humanities research applications, such as concordances or computational linguistics.
tools.name: ALGOL

tools.detail: EULER was a general programming language proposed as a successor to and with many of the characteristics of ALGOL 60. Extended EULER, which included string-handling facilities based on ALGOL W, was useful to humanities research for search, frequency count and related operations on text.
tools.name: EULER

tools.detail: PL/C (Programming Language Cornell) was a programming language based on PL/I developed at Cornell University in the early 1970s as an entry-level language to facilitate programming instruction. It was occasionally used to introduce humanists to programming concepts, though it is unclear whether it was used for humanities-oriented research in its own right.
tools.name: PL/C

tools.detail: SPITBOL (Speedy Implementation of SNOBOL) was a complied implementation of SNOBOL4 with additional features, such as string reversal, of particular interest to researchers in the humanities.
tools.name: SPITBOL

tools.detail: ProIcon was an implementation and expansion of the Icon programming language for Macintosh computers developed in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Though still best described as a programming language, it was also referred to as a text study and manipulation system, and as an information system. ProIcon functioned as a program development system, with an included an editor and an error handling system, and was compatible with Icon 7.
tools.name: ProIcon

tools.detail: AWK is a programming language well suited to text processing first developed at Bell Labs in the late 1970s. It was particularly useful to humanists in the late 1980s and early 1990s, and was notably used to develop parts of the ARTFL project.
tools.name: AWK

tools.detail: Prolog is a general purpose programming language first developed in the early 1970s with a particular value to computational lingusitics. Within the humanities, it was applied to natural language processing.
tools.name: Prolog

tools.detail: LISP is a longstanding high-level programming language first developed in the late 1950s. Within the humanities, it was applied to computational linguistics and natural language processing research.
tools.name: LISP

tools.detail:
Umigon is a tool used for the sentiment analysis of texts. It is one of the tools of the Nocode app which is a suite of text analysis tools. Results can be exported in Excel or CSV format for further analysis.  It was formerly a stand alone  web-based and open-source tool for the sentiment analysis of tweets. From a person's Twitter handle, Umigon retrieved that account's tweets and processed them for sentiment while accounting for factual statements (ex: "I hate war" will be classified has negative, and "war in Syria" will be classified as neutral). Tweets could also be pasted manually in the entry box provided. Beyond sentiment analysis, Umigon could identify characteristics such as whether the tweet contains a question, whether it contains possible promotional/commercial subject matter, or temporal indicators based on tense. The developer of this application can be reached on Twitter.
As of April 2022, Umigon has been archived after a long period without new developments.
tools.name: Umigon

tools.detail: CheckText is a free, web-based text analysis tool. Users can paste in text, upload it from their files, or import content from a web page. For each text, CheckText generates statistics such as word count, syllable count or number of complex words, provides a reading ease and level breakdown, and graphs the most frequent words. The tool also offers a uniqueness check aimed at detecting plagiarism, and generates a PDF report containing the full text with the statistical and readability data.
tools.name: CheckText

tools.detail: Discursis is a tool for analyzing text-based natural language with a focus on sequential analysis. It is particularly desgined to work with texts that have an internal temporal structure, such as a transcribed conversation. For each text, it generates a statistics-based internal language model and applies tagging to each temporal unit detected. The model and tagging are then used as the basis for an interactive visualization which permits examination at a various levels of granularity, ranging from a whole-text to a unit-by-unit level; it can also show topic usage patterns within the text. Users must purchase a license; both student and academic trial licenses are available.
tools.name: Discursis

tools.detail: Leximancer is an application for identifying key concepts in a text, and exploring the results through interactive visualizations and data exports. It includes concept and network cloud visualizations, a sentiment lens, a query system, and multiple data export options for futher analysis. The system accepts texts in a variety of formats including plain text, CSV, HTML and XML, and supports 17 languages beyond English. Users can either purchase a license for the desktop version (Windows and OS X supported), or purchase access to the online LexiPortal, which charges based on months of usage rather than on a subscription basis. A free trial of the LexiPortal is also available.
tools.name: Leximancer

tools.detail: Jigsaw is a free visual analytics application for exploring collections of documents such as text or spreadsheets. It is aimed at analysists and researchers, particularly to "help analysts reach more timely and accurate understandings of the larger stories and important concepts embedded throughout textual results" via a collection of visualizations representing aspects such as important entities and their interconnections. The visualizations include graph, temporal and connections-based, and can be viewed on a document or corpus level.
tools.name: Jigsaw

tools.detail: Alt.Text is a free, working prototype application for exploring a text on both an outline and content level via a graphical user interface. It breaks down texts into components such as sections, passages or documents, and permits users to leverage these components to create outlines and break off sections. Alt.Text includes three interfaces: the Document Editor (define sections, create outlines), the Section Editor (define passages of text within a given section), and the Outline Viewer (choose which passages to include in an outline section). Alt.Text is under active development, and is available for download in both Windows and OS X versions.
tools.name: Alt.Text

tools.detail: Data Desk  is a commercial application for data exploration, analysis and visualization available for both OS X and Windows systems. It uses a graphical user interface to provide numerous tools for working with data, and can generate several distinct views. Notably, the program is designed from an exploratory rather than inferential analysis perspective. An academic license is available for users with a .edu email address; academic users without a .edu address can purchase by contacting Data Description, Inc. directly. A trial license is also available.
tools.name: Data Desk

tools.detail: Dataplot is a free software system for data analysis, including characterization, visualization and modelling. It was developed in FORTRAN 77, and has been in continuous development since 1978. Dataplot is well-documented, with numerous tutorials for using and extending it. In addiiton, over 30 graphic types are supported, such as histograms, box plots, scatter plots and normal probability plots. This tool is currently available in Unix, Linux, OS X and Windows versions. Dataplot is open source, but is trademarked rather than licensed.
tools.name: Dataplot

tools.detail: Coggle is a web-based tool for visualizing and applying non-linear structuring to information. Though Coggle has been used for mind mapping, it is primarily a method of documenting branching and non-linear information, and encompassing multiple perspectives. It utlizes a drag and drop interface for integrating images, permits multiple users to edit at the same time without causing data conflicts, and supports Markdown and LaTeX formatting. Coggle diagrams can be interlinked, branches of one diagram can be spawned off into its own diagram connected back to the original, and individual branches can be linked via hashtags. The tool includes an API that permits users to interface their diagrams with other programs and manupulate or examine them, and diagrams can also be exported in various formats such as plain-text outline, vector PDFs or images. Coggle is free except where users require more than 100 monthly active users or a closed source version.
tools.name: Coggle

tools.detail: Community Contributed Collection (CoCoCo) is web software developed by the RunCoCo Project at the University of Oxford for collecting, cataloguing and managing web content such as text or uploaded files contributed by a community of users. It enables administrators to assess contributions for quality, approve project-appropriate contributions, and apply metadata where required. Once a contribution is approved, it is available for searching and browsing through the provided interface. CoCoCo utilizes Ruby on Rails, and is available under an Open Source version 3.0 license.
tools.name: Community Contributed Collection (CoCoCo)

tools.detail: Project Quincy is a free, open source Django application and MySQL database for tracing the development of social networks and instititions across time and space. Aimed at historians, it enables users to map networks in historical documentation such as biographic, organizational, correspondance or location. Creator Jean Bauer has developed Project Quincy as a single generalizable and extensible database with applications beyond mapping historic connections. All code is available via Github repository, or by contacting the creator directly.
tools.name: Project Quincy

tools.detail: Lexos is a free, web-based workflow for text analysis offered by Wheaton College's Lexomics Project. Lexos is the most recent and distinct iteration of the Lexomics system of tools, enabling users to upload a text and use the Lexos interface to apply transformations, visualizations, scrubbing and analytic processes without needing to re-add the text for each step.
tools.name: Lexos

tools.detail: Visual Understanding Environment (VUE) is a free, open source application for mapping concepts, ideas and digital content. It enables users to generate nodes and links, and apply a simple set of tools to explore the relationships. VUE is, in the words of its developers, an application to "integrate, organize and contextualize electronic content" in research or learning environments. Its tools include visualization, dynamic content mapping, semantic mapping, enhanced pathways and search functions.
tools.name: Visual Understanding Environment (VUE)

tools.detail: NodeBox is an open-source package of tools that includes the capacity to visualize large data sets. It utilizes interconnected nodes to generate and manipulate data visualizations, and can import data either from common programs such as Excel, or from custom user-developed importers.
tools.name: NodeBox

tools.detail: Qualrus is a commercial application for qualitative data analysis, including data coding and statistics functions. It can analyze data from a wide variety of sources, including common text, web, image, video and audio files. The data coding functions are supplemented by machine learning processes to assist data processing and analysis. In terms of analysis, it offers a number of common text analysis functions including tokenization, co-occurences, and Boolean search, and can visualize a network view of interrelationships. It is particularly aimed at academic and institutional applications, and both student and free trial versions are avaiable.
tools.name: Qualrus

tools.detail: ANTHROPAC, now in version 4.98, is a long-standing menu-driven DOS program developed for working with anthropological and other cultural data. It assists both the collection and analysis of datasets, and can accommodate both qualitiative and quantitative information. ANTHROPAC includes analytic tools such as consensus analysis, factor analysis, cluster analysis and correspondance analysis, in addition to data manipulation and transformation functions. It imports and exports data via ASCII formats, and includes an extensive reference manual, a user's guide and a methods guide tailored for cultural domain analysis.
tools.name: ANTHROPAC

tools.detail: SwiftRiver is a free, open source platform for filtering and processing large amounts of information. In particular, it can gather and filter data from common web sources such as email, Twitter or RSS. It also enables users to define 'buckets' according to their own criteria rather than relying on, for example, the information's social media popularity status. Utilizing a combination of filters and buckets, users create 'rivers' of data populated by their chosen sources. Developer Ushahidi has made all code available for general access via Github, though a custom, full-service, hosted version is available for a fee by contacting the company directly.
tools.name: SwiftRiver

tools.detail: Siena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis) is a free program for statistical analysis developed particularly to work with social network data, but also applicable to other forms of network data. It models network dynamics via Markov chain models; this approach is best applied to data where relations between actors and their behaviour can be treated as a state rather than as an event. Siena's statistical analysis processes can be time-consuming, as the system works via computer simulation of the network. It was in continuous development from 2001 through 2010, releasing versions up to 3.2. Development on Siena as a stand-alone program has concuded, and the project has shifted focus to RSiena, a version of Siena deployed in R.
tools.name: Siena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis)

tools.detail: RSiena is a free, open source social network analysis package for R. It replaces Siena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis), which was a stand-alone program for Windows. Like its predecessor, RSiena is optimized for social network data, but is also applicable to other forms of network data, and relies on Markov chain models to generate network dynamics. This approach is best applied to data where relations between actors and their behaviour can be treated as a state rather than as an event. Users not familiar with R can run RSiena via the provided graphical user interface.
tools.name: RSiena

tools.detail: SARIT (Search and Retrieval of Indic Texts) is a library of Indic texts with tools for search, retrieval and analysis built into the website. This includes options to apply a KWIC or concordance encompassing all matching texts for a site search. SARIT was developed from a modified version of PhiloLogic. The full SARIT collection with TEI-compatible markup is also available via Github.
tools.name: SARIT (Search and Retrieval of Indic Texts)

tools.detail: Carrot2 is a free, open source search clustering engine with additional document categorization functions. For each set of search terms, Carrot2 provides a topic tree and subtopics built from the search results, and generates visualizations that enable users to quickly overview their search. Searches can be filtered according to source, such as Bing, image files or the Wikipedia, results can be clustered according to several presets such as K-means or URL, or filtered by country and langauge. Carrot2 enables users to download results in ranges from 50 to 200 for further analysis.
tools.name: Carrot2

tools.detail: Casual is a free, open source tool for generating a visualization of concepts from a key word search. It uses Wikipedia for conceptual information, and can also include Google Image search results where applicable. Users can click on a term to generate a new search from that term, while image results can be rearranged by clicking and dragging them to the desired location. Casual can produce visualizations ranging from 10 to 400 concepts in size, and can retrieve information for queries in a wide variety of languages. This tool is no longer supported; development appears to have ceased in 2009.
tools.name: Casual

tools.detail: Digress.it was a free, open source WordPress plugin for annotating texts on the paragraph level, particularly of article to book-length documents. It permitted blog-like threaded discussions to occur in the margins of the text, and was aimed at facilitating scholarly, literary, political and other discussions. While the main website is no longer available, Digress.it is still available via the WordPress plugin directory.
tools.name: Digress.it

tools.detail: With ContaWords you can quickly and easily get a frequency analysis of your texts (pdf, html, txt). The results can be downloaded and easily handled. When you give ContaWords a task, it first reads the words of a text file and decides what part of speech to assign to each word (credit-Noun-credit but credit-Verb-to_credit). It then begins to count how many times a word appears in the text in every possible way (credits, credit, credited… etc). ContaWords can also take into account that a sequence of words can, for example, be the name of an organization, a person or an entity (Named Entity Recognition). Besides all this, ContaWords can find sequences of two words that seem to appear together more often than would be expected, such as "monetary policy " or "fiscal balance ".
tools.name: ContaWords

tools.detail: Alveo is a platform for data discovery and analysis focused on communication data such as speech, text or video. Developed by the University of Western Sydney, researchers can use the Alveo infrastructure to store data, create collections, develop workflows, and analyze datasets with Alveo's built-in tools. The tools available span multiple disciplines and include common functions such as tokenization and concordance, plus interfaces between Alveo and other common analysis tools such as Apache's UIMA for NLP, and with programming languages such as Python and Java. Users can segmented and recombined data from multiple collections into a new, focused dataset for close analysis. Collection creators can set their own license and access rights, and users of a collection must accept the creator's conditions in order to use data from it. User accounts are free, but must be requested from and approved by Alveo.
tools.name: Alveo

tools.detail: SemLens is a tool for visualizing and analyzing RDF data developed as part of the Visual Data Web toolset and based on the Adobe Flex open source framework. Using SPARQL to access the user's dataset, it arranges RDF data into a scatter plot which can be analyzed via semantic lenses generated based on the dataset, and with logical operators. The tool provides a global overview of the user's dataset, and can do so even for large datasets.
tools.name: SemLens

tools.detail: gFacet is a tool for graph-based visualization of RDF data developed as part of the Visual Data Web toolset and based on the Adobe Flex open source framework. Using SPARQL to access the user's dataset, it integrates filtering based on facets represented as nodes within the visualization to enable users to select which they wish to work with and create custom search interfaces.
tools.name: gFacet

tools.detail: tFacet applies known interaction concepts to allow hierarchical faceted exploration of RDF data. The aim is to facilitate ordinary users to formulate semantically unambiguous queries so as to support the fast and precise access to information. Used interaction concepts are e.g. a directory tree and interchangeable columns that are already well-known from other applications. The directory tree, for example, is used to enable the intuitive exploration and selection of hierarchical facets. tFacet is based on the open source framework Adobe Flex and uses SPARQL to access RDF datasets.
tools.name: tFacet

tools.detail: minezy is a prototype application for exploring and mining large email archives. Its interface is designed to make it easy to find the answers to common questions: who the message originator was, when messages were sent, how frequently, who was included in the exchange, and the subject and content. The app interface is designed around search, filters and a series of panels that open to the right when results and sub-results are clicked on. The prototype can be tried out via the minezy website, and is pre-loaded with the Enron collection of emails for exploration.
tools.name: minezy

tools.detail: WIScker is a tool for generating corpi from Wikipedia articles. It takes all of the various versions and edits of an article over time and creates a comparative corpus out of them. The corpus can then be analyzed using a built-in button to access voyant tools, or can be exported in a text file in various different formats.
tools.name: WIScker

tools.detail: Voyant is a suite of text analysis tools that work on the web. The default skin provides basic tools for analyzing a single text or a collection.
tools.name: Voyant (Default Skin)

tools.detail: This tool will look through a collection of documents and returns the relative frequencies for whatever keywords you tell it to look for. The output is in csv format and contains relative frequencies for each word, as well as the sum of the relative frequencies of all keywords.
tools.name: Keyword Frequency Analyzer

tools.detail:
A very simple/specialized piece of Java code that takes a csv file produced by "Youtube Comment Scraper" - http://ytcomments.klostermann.ca/ and collapses the replies down into the same categories that basic comments are under. This makes it easier to compare all comments to each other.

NOTE: The name of the csv file to be parsed has to be written into the code, assigned to the variable "inFile".
tools.name: Youtube Scraper CSV Cleaner

tools.detail: party
tools.name: BJP

tools.detail: Hypothesis is an online annotation tool. It allows you to see community annotations and store your own annotations for anything on the internet.
tools.name: Hypothesis

tools.detail: Critic Markup is a simple plain text markdown language that can be used for noting changes and revisions in text over time. It’s a simple language that has toolkits that allow it to be used in some popular applications.
tools.name: Critic Markup

tools.detail: EgoWeb 2.0 is a tool for graphing social networks. It allows for various types of data collection to be used, and can present and export data. It’s open source, and allows for a number of different data collection methods.
tools.name: EgoWeb 2.0

tools.detail: graph-tool is a python library implemented in C++ that allows for a number of statistical analyses with graphs.
tools.name: graph-tool

tools.detail: LIWC does a detailed linguistic analysis of a piece of writing, looking at a variety of different factors withing that writing. It allows for a variety of different analyses,
tools.name: Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count

tools.detail: This tool simply takes HTML and returns it without the HTML tags.
tools.name: Zubrag HTML Tags Stripper

tools.detail: igraph is a network analysis tool that can be used in R, python, and C++. It's focused on usability, portability, and ease of use.
tools.name: igraph

tools.detail: Igraph is a series of network analysis function libraries and tools built into C, C++, R, and python. It’s free, open source, and focuses on usability and portability.
tools.name: igraph

tools.detail: Cytoscape does a number of tasks related to network analysis and visualization. It’s geared towards working with web-related systems, but can be used to work with any kind of attribute.
tools.name: Cytoscape

tools.detail: Linkurious is a network analysis and visualization tool. It’s easy to use, and can be used with a variety of graph databases. It provides a variety of analytics and visualizations.
tools.name: Linkurious

tools.detail: Lynks is a system that allows for simple and straightforward sharing and exploration of various kinds of network data. It focuses on ease of sharing and visualization, as well as collaboration on networks. You can create a network from scratch on it, or you can use existing data to populate the network visualization.
tools.name: Lynks

tools.detail: Lynks is a system that allows for simple and straightforward sharing and exploration of various kinds of network data. It focuses on ease of sharing and visualization, as well as collaboration on networks. You can create a network from scratch on it, or you can use existing data to populate the network visualization.
tools.name: Lynks

tools.detail: Lynks is a system that allows for simple and straightforward sharing and exploration of various kinds of network data. It focuses on ease of sharing and visualization, as well as collaboration on networks. You can create a network from scratch on it, or you can use existing data to populate the network visualization.
tools.name: Lynks

tools.detail: Lynks is a system that allows for simple and straightforward sharing and exploration of various kinds of network data. It focuses on ease of sharing and visualization, as well as collaboration on networks. You can create a network from scratch on it, or you can use existing data to populate the network visualization.
tools.name: Lynks

tools.detail: Lynks is a system that allows for simple and straightforward sharing and exploration of various kinds of network data. It focuses on ease of sharing and visualization, as well as collaboration on networks. You can create a network from scratch on it, or you can use existing data to populate the network visualization.
tools.name: Lynks

tools.detail: Neo4j Console is a fairly simple to use visualization graph tool for relational databases. It allows you to add databases and visualize them using queries.
tools.name: Neo4j Console

tools.detail: NetDraw is a tool for creating visualizations of networks. It can create various visualizations of several data types, and allows for customization of many aspects of their relationships.
tools.name: NetDraw

tools.detail: NetworkX is a python software package that allows for the visualization and analysis of various networks. It's flexible in they types of things that it can show through networking.
tools.name: NetworkX

tools.detail: json-extractor.py is a simple command line tool for creating csv files from large json datasets.
tools.name: JSON Extractor

tools.detail: nodegoat creates visualizations and provides a graphical user interface for the maintenance of data. It combines a variety of data management functions into one program.
tools.name: nodegoat

tools.detail: NodeXL is a template for Microsoft XL that greatly increases the usability and visualization capabilities of Microsoft XL. It can be used to quickly and easily create visualizations within Microsoft XL.
tools.name: NodeXL

tools.detail: Popoto.js is a graph searching and visualization too that's programmed in Javascript. It's free to use and has a variety of different searching and display options available for users.
tools.name: Popoto.js

tools.detail: Knot uses a variety of digital visualization tools to study historical social networks. It looks at the actual construction of digital graphs and networks and how that construction can be used to understand the ways in which social networks exist.
tools.name: Density Design - Knot

tools.detail: Voyant 2.0 is a complete rewrite of Voyant. It provides a suite of text analysis tools that will work with most texts you can upload or find on the web. These tools are combined in skins. For documentation see Documentation for Voyant 2.0
tools.name: Voyant Tools 2.0 (Corpus View)

tools.detail: A java tool that allows for the creation of graphs and databases through the creation and connection of entities. It runs on a variety of platforms, and allows for a variety of configurations across multiple machines and users.
tools.name: Segrada

tools.detail: UCINET is a social media analysis set for software that integrates with NetDraw. It allows for a variety of different searches and analyses to be done with the social networks data in it.
tools.name: UCINET

tools.detail: Voyant ScatterPlot visualizes a corpus using correspondence analysis or document similarity. This can give you ideas about how to further analyze a corpus. Documentation can be found in the Guide.
tools.name: Voyant 2.0: ScatterPlot

tools.detail: Bubblelines lets you compare the distribution of words across documents. Each document is a horizontal line with bubbles where the word appears. Documentation here.
tools.name: Voyant 2.0: Bubblelines

tools.detail: Voyant Knots is a visualization where a line is bent at every instance of a word forming knots. If you visualize multiple terms you will get multiple twisted lines. The Documentation can be found here.
tools.name: Voyant 2.0: Knots

tools.detail: Voyant Knots is a visualization where a line is bent at every instance of a word forming knots. If you visualize multiple terms you will get multiple twisted lines. The Documentation can be found here.
tools.name: Voyant 2.0: Knots

tools.detail: Voyant Knots is a visualization where a line is bent at every instance of a word forming knots. If you visualize multiple terms you will get multiple twisted lines. The Documentation can be found here.
tools.name: Voyant 2.0: Knots

tools.detail: Voyant 2.0  Terms Radio shows the high frequency terms scrolling by as if broadcast. You can select the words to watch rise and fall. You can control the speed and number of words. Documentation here.
tools.name: Voyant 2.0: Terms Radio

tools.detail: Sorts large CSV by splitting them into smaller files, when memory is an issue.
tools.name: CSV Sort

tools.detail:
Takes a list of newline separated items and sorts them from most appearances to least appearances. Was used in conjunction with Ryan Chartier's JSON extractor code so has hardcoded cases relating to that (for example, will also treat strings separated by semi-colons as discrete items when certain command-line arguments are used). Allows for a cutoff after [x] items, putting the remainder into an "other" category.
Output is in CSV format.
tools.name: Frequency Sorter

tools.detail:
Code from an iPython notebook, based on:

http://nealcaren.web.unc.edu/an-introduction-to-text-analysis-with-python-part-3/

This notebook shows how to conduct sentiment analysis on a collection of passages (e.g. Tweets) using dictionaries of positive and negative words.
tools.name: Complex Sentiment Analysis

tools.detail:
Code from an iPython notebook, based on:
http://nealcaren.web.unc.edu/an-introduction-to-text-analysis-with-python-part-1/

This notebook walks the user through analyzing a single string of text by creating custom dictionaries of positive and negative words.
tools.name: Simple Sentiment Analysis

tools.detail: A simple command line tool for expanding warc files. Warc files are archives of webpages, as provided by the Internet Archive. Input is warc files and output can either be a warc file or as faithful a recreation of the website(s) contained within the warc file as can be managed.
tools.name: Warc Extractor

tools.detail: twarc is a command line tool and Python library for archiving Twitter JSON data. Each tweet is represented as a JSON object that is exactly what was returned from the Twitter API. Tweets are stored as line-oriented JSON.
tools.name: Twitter Archiver (TWARC)

tools.detail: This free web-based tool allows you to scrape the comments from a YouTube video and save them in either a JSON or CSV format. The project is open source, and its code is available on github.
tools.name: YouTube Comment Scraper

tools.detail: EVI-LINHD is a free and open-source cloud platform to create Digital Humanities projects. It contains a range of tools, including Wordpress for web design, Omeka for creating digital libraries, and an XML-TEI digital edition tool and processing model based on eXist. Users are able to create full DH projects using the platform.
tools.name: EVI-LINHD

tools.detail: EVI-LINHD is a free and open-source cloud platform to create Digital Humanities projects. It contains a range of tools, including Wordpress for web design, Omeka for creating digital libraries, and an XML-TEI digital edition tool and processing model based on eXist. Users are able to create full DH projects using the platform.
tools.name: EVI-LINHD

tools.detail: Zenodo is a catch-all repository for research data. It accepts all research data, with no requirements on format, size, access restrictions, or license. It is intended to support storage, curation, and publication of big research data. It was developed by the OpenAIRE partner CERN, responding to a request by the European Commission to create an open catch-all repository for all EC funded research.
tools.name: Zenodo

tools.detail: PyDelta is a commandline tool for analyzing the Delta (stylistic differences) between two texts. This measure is used in computational stylistics, particularly for trying to identify the given author of a text. PyDelta is a direct implementation of 3 algorithms described by Argamon in a paper on John Burrows Delta.
tools.name: PyDelta

tools.detail: Text Analysis Online is an API hosted with Mashape. It provides a range of text analysis procedures including Tokenization, Tagging, Part-of-Speech(POS), and sentiment analysis, built on top of NLP tools such as NLTK, TextBlob, and Pattern. The individual procedures can be tested on the TextAnalysisOnline website and the API can be used on Mashape.
tools.name: Text Analysis Online

tools.detail:
Part of the McGill Characterization Process family. Parses all the texts in a data directory and picks out all the characters and their aliases. Output is in JSON format and is required for the rest of the tools in this family.

Extensive setup required. Please consult the readme on github for setup instructions.
tools.name: McGill Characterization Process - Character Parser

tools.detail:
Part of the McGill Characterization Process family. Examines all the texts in a data directory and uses the output from the Character Parser to pick out all the aliases for the characters in the aforementioned texts. Output is in JSON format and is required for the rest of the tools in this family.

Extensive setup required. Please consult the readme on github for setup instructions.
tools.name: McGill Characterization Process - Alias Identifier

tools.detail:
Part of the McGill Characterization Process family. Examines all the texts in a data directory and uses the output from the Alias Identifier to find the collocates for the words in the aforementioned texts. Output is in .tsv format and is required for the rest of the tools in this family.

Extensive setup required. Please consult the readme on github for setup instructions.
tools.name: McGill Characterization Process - Collocate Parser

tools.detail:
Part of the McGill Characterization Process family. Examines all the texts in a data directory, and using the analysis already done by the Collocate Parser, Alias Identifier, and Character Parser, gives data for the centrality of characters for each text, allowing the texts to be ranked against each other based on this.

Extensive setup required. Please consult the readme on github for setup instructions.
tools.name: McGill Characterization Process - Calculate Character Centrality

tools.detail: http://www.htpow.com/high-powered-30000mw-blue-laserpointer-445nm-worlds-brightest-p-1027.html
tools.name: Laser Pointer

tools.detail: http://www.htpow.com/high-powered-30000mw-blue-laserpointer-445nm-worlds-brightest-p-1027.html
tools.name: Laser Pointer

tools.detail: http://www.htpow.com/high-powered-30000mw-blue-laserpointer-445nm-worlds-brightest-p-1027.html
tools.name: Laser Pointer

tools.detail: .Due to its strong straight light, laser pens (pointers) are widely used in teaching, astronomy etc. Just push the button, then you will see striking light shoot. It is alright to point at any targets such as photos, PowerPoint, monitor etc. It may be the proferred choic for astronomy fans, laser fans.
tools.name: Laser Pointer

tools.detail:
Parses text tagged by the Stanford named entity recognizer in order to collect and analyze mentions of locations. Also incorporates the Google API in order to geocode those locations and, ultimately, mark them on a map.

This code was written in an IPython Notebook, so the code below is actually a collection of scattered code snippets. Please see the repository on github for full details and documentation, or the Methods Common recipe ( http://methodi.ca/recipes/mapping-locations-corpus ) for a step-by-step guide.

NOTE: Users will be required to acquire their own Google API key, store it in a text file, and then point the code to that text file. Instructions can be found in the IPython Notebook itself. Search for "api_key_file" to find the line in code that needs to be changed.
tools.name: Textual Geography Analyzer

This notebook's aim is to showcase how to conduct Multiple Correspondence Analysis (MCA) on a corpus. In this notebook, we will be using a collection of novels by different authors i.e The Return of Sherlock Holmes by Arthur Conan Doyle, Lady Susan by Jane Austen, and A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens taken from Project Gutenberg.

First will gather and load in all the text.
We clean them and break them down into tokens.
We will categorize the tokens using General Inquirer Category taken from Harvard to conduct our analysis.
From there we will conduct MCA on the results and plot the results on a scatter plot.
tools.name: Multiple Correspondence Analysis and Content Analysis

tools.detail: This is a Windows program for generating and searching a KWIC concordance of a document ("KWIC" = "Keywords in Context"). A KWIC concordance is a list of the different words occurring in the document, with each instance of each word shown in context (that is, within a phrase). Word frequency is shown. Context size is user-definable, anything from 3 to 19 words long. The software acts on text files and on MS Word docx files, skipping over "stop" words.  The concordance can be displayed alphabetically or by frequency, and can be written to a file.After a concordance is generated it may be searched for specified keywords.  You can search also for word patterns (such as "s?t*ing").  You can search for a specified word (or word pattern) which has another specified word (or word pattern) close to it (that is, within the same context).There is no limit on the size of an input file. You can tell the program to allow or disallow hyphenated words or words with numerals. You can tell it to include only words which occur with more than a specified frequency. Stop words may be read from a file. This software may be used with text in languages other than English, in particular, with French, German, Italian, Spanish and Latin text.
tools.name: Search KWIC Concordance

tools.detail: Analyse-it Method Validation Edition provides the statistical analysis you need to validate and verify analytical and diagnostic methods to meet the demands of regulatory compliance. With support for 11 CLSI protocols, it lets you:•	Validate or verify analytical performance characteristics (precision, trueness, linearity, interferences, detection capability) of a measurement procedure to ensure they meet requirements for intended use or manufacturer's claims.•	Compare methods to establish the real-world performance of a method against a reference method, or ensure comparability between two methods when making changes. Includes Deming, Weighted Deming, and Passing-Bablok regression, plus Bland-Altman limits of agreement.•	Evaluate the diagnostic ability of a test to discriminate between two outcomes and compare test performance to find the most effective one. Includes ROC curves and Delong-Delong Clarke Pearson curve comparisons.•	Establish a reference interval for a population of healthy individuals, or verify that existing intervals are transferable between laboratories or measurement procedures. Includes normal, quantile, robust bi-weight quantile, bootstrapped quantile, & Harrell-Davis quantile reference ranges.
tools.name: Analyse-it Method Validation Edition

Includes ANOVA, multiple comparisons, and an extensive range of parametric and non-parametric tests.•	Discover relationships between variables and identify important factors with powerful regression and model fitting techniques. Include linear and logistic regression, with simple functions, or advanced models with crossed, polynomial and factorial terms.•	Get insight into highly complex data by reducing dimensionality to get a clearer picture of the underlying structure. tools.detail:
Topincs is a online database software. Given a data model, it allows data to be recorded and files to be uploaded and annotated through forms, data and files to be displayed and navigated through interconnected data sheets, and all that searched in the index. It overcomes the rigidity of relational databases by using semantic technology. In the simplest use case, a group of users can collaboratively edit information and upload files from any device with a web browser and an internet connection. Development time ranges between 1 and 8 hours.

By designing and implementing services, the data can be manipulated, transformed and aggregated through an virtual object oriented programming interface driven by the data model. This allows sophisticated use cases where different user groups with different rights are presented a completely different application working on the same database. In these cases development time ranges between 2 and 20 days.

A Topincs online database can be rented for a monthly fee. Topincs provide all services related to an online database: data modeling, programming, and support. They have special rates for educational institutions. Topincs can also be used as a Platform as a Service where the dark art of Topincs modeling and development must be studied online. The underlying semantic technology, Topic Maps, is taught there through hands on examples and will change your view on information technology.
tools.name: Topincs

Easier to detect the trend and keep track based on the visualisation and using real time data. There are free useful ready-made templates available for personal use. Besides research, education and quality industries, MyIndicators can be used by anyone who wishes to improve performance, achieve personal goals, promote healthy habits or gain personal insights. Educational and students discounts are available.

tools.detail: This software  is for indexing and searching Word docx files, HTML files, XML files, text files or files of a similar kind (such as XML files) in any folder of a hard disk, CD-ROM, etc.This program does not simply create a list of files or simply search for character strings in a file. It indexes every word in every file, and any file containing a particular set of words (or any of those words, or an exact phrase) can be found by searching for those words.  Indexed files can be edited lightly without needing to re-index.This software consists of two integrated modules: 1. An index module which is used to create an index of the files to be searched. 2.  A search module which is used to search those files.The index module is capable of indexing a hierarchy of over 1000 files, totaling over 20 MB, and containing over 50,000 different words. Even with that number of different words the search module returns results in a few seconds. The results of a search are displayed automatically in a text box or in your default web browser (with links to the files containing the words searched for).

The output may be further input into other advanced statistical analytics or data mining modules available in AroniSmartIntelligence™,  including regression analysis, econometrics, segmentation and Bayesian models.

tools.detail: RefSeek is still in public beta, but I’ve had a lot of luck with this search engine. RefSeek gives students access to more than 1 billion documents, web pages, books, journals, and newspapers. What I really appreciate about the site is how clean the interface is—no ads, sponsored links or commercial results appear when you use RefSeek.For a full review visit: http://eoinlong.com/
tools.name: RefSeek

tools.detail: I would consider myself to be a visual learner.  I surround myself with gifs and memes, and when it comes to academia I gravitate towards infographics, mind-maps and charts to observe key pieces of information.  So it’s not surprising that I chose a graphics based tool to review.  In my area of study (Digital Humanities and IT), we cross paths with a myriad of visualisations every day, in many different formats.  I think then it is prudent that we should be able to create our own graphics in order to convey, share or focus our knowledge or opinions, even if we have a lower level of computer literacy.Enter “Canva.com”.  Canva has deemed itself the “Amazingly Simple Graphic Design Software”, and it is definitely true to its word.  It is an open source software and its simplicity in my opinion is much needed.  I am familiar with Photoshop, Gimp, Photoplus and InDesign but as most of us know Photoshop et al, can be convoluted, time consuming and of course very expensive.  Canva was created in 2012 by Melanie Perkins of Sydney, Australia.  The idea for Canva stemmed from the fact that whilst teaching graphic design to her students, they struggled with the basics.  Perkins then formed a partnership with Cliff Obrecht and from there they initially created Fusion Books - an online design tool for designing high school yearbooks.  They later went on to launch Canva after realising that the technology they developed had even more potential. The website as mentioned previously, is www.canva.com.  Its interface, as it should be, is bright and simple, and very encouraging.  Canva may be used for designing posters, profile pictures, Facebook banners, infographics and pie/bar charts.  It revolves entirely around controls such as drag-and-drop, which makes adding, removing, and editing elements onto your canvas a cakewalk.  Canva stores a vast amount of text and images in its repository, the one slight snag is that you will have to pay $1 per image once your design is downloaded (which is still rather inexpensive).  Also, having said that, the software allows the user to upload many personal images for manipulation, so downloading the software’s images is not completely necessary.  When it comes to its colour scheme, at first glance Canva provides a palette of up to about 8 colours, but if you’re after a specific colour or hue then the colour-picker provided may help with that and it even allows you to enter a hexadecimal code for that specific hue.  There are also video tutorials available upon launching your account of how to work your way around the website.  Users can also create videos and gif images which can then be uploaded to social media accounts.  Your work can then be saved and exported to PDF and PNG depending on what it is you have created. If you are a design pro, then you may find Canva a bit limiting in what it has to offer.  Canva is very much aware of this, as it never had the intention of taking over pro tools such as the aforementioned Photoshop or InDesign.  With Canva the everyday user has everything to gain and nothing to lose by utilising it, but the professional has nothing to lose and not much else to gain.  Regardless of this, for the user who simply wants to make a flyer, poster, invitation or meme then Canva will be your best friend.  It helps the average user to overcome any design fears.  Canva employs designers and also reaches out to photographers and illustrators to share their works on the website for us to avail of.  It also provides creative inspiration via a stream of designs previously made by registered users, and this is why I feel it deserves recognition on DiRT.Since its origination in 2012, Canva has been growing from strength to strength, opening an office in Manila in 2014 and eventually raising additional funds of approx. 6 million dollars in 2015.  It also gained new investors that year, including Hollywood actor Woody Harrelson.  From reading reviews about Canva the outlook on the entire software looks positive.  It also seems to be escalating in rank on many tech based websites.  Canva has since created a workplace version of their software, which allows for team collaboration on various potential projects.  Smart Company gave Canva a gleaming review and listed it number 5 out of a total 75 in its article: “75 Best Tools for Skyrocketing Business Growth in 2016”.  If you have access to internet and a computer you’re basically more than half way there to designing your first masterpiece.  Canva is a smart tool that everyone should experience, for the computer savvy and the not so computer savvy.
tools.name: Canva "The Amazingly Simple Graphic Design Software"

tools.detail:
Sigma is a JavaScript library dedicated to graph drawing. It makes it easy to publish networks on Web pages, and allows developers to integrate network exploration in rich Web applications.

It is highly interactive and allows a researcher to extend their work from a dedicated graph analysis package such as Gephi and share it via the web to allow for communication of research outputs, while permitting viewers to explore and discover their own findings from the raw graph network.

tools.detail: EXMARaLDA is a system for working with oral corpora on a computer. It consists of a transcription and annotation tool (Partitur-Editor), a tool for managing corpora (Corpus-Manager) and a query and analysis tool (EXAKT).EXMARaLDA supports the time-aligned transcription of digital audio or video, a flexible annotation for freely choosable categories, the systematic documentation of a corpus through metadata, a flexible visualisation of transcription data in different layouts and document formats, as well as the computer-assisted querying of transcription, annotation and metadata.EXMARaLDA works with XML based data formats which interoperate with one another and with the formats of other widely used tools (like Praat, ELAN, Transcriber). This enables a flexible processing and sustainable usage of the data.
tools.name: EXMARaLDA

tools.detail: corpkit is a tool for doing corpus linguistics.It does a lot of the usual things, like parsing, concordancing and keywording, but also extends their potential significantly: you can concordance by searching for combinations of lexical and grammatical features, and can do keywording of lemmas, of subcorpora compared to corpora, or of words in certain positions within clauses.Corpus interrogations can be quickly edited and visualised in complex ways, or saved and loaded within projects, or exported to formats that can be handled by other tools.corpkit accomplishes all of this by leveraging a number of sophisticated programming libraries, including pandas, matplotlib, scipy, Tkinter, tkintertable and Stanford CoreNLP.
tools.name: Corpkit

tools.detail: Aimed at the TEI editing community and intended to be run inside oXygen, the Data Dictionary Generator (DDG) generates profiles of every element and attribute appearing in a TEI file. Each entry includes a definition from the TEI Guidelines, a local, project-specific definition (if provided), and a brief snapshot of how the element or attribute is actually being used. By making it easy to compare these three things, the DDG aims to help project editors reflect on current practice within their projects and quickly create stronger encoding guidelines for their collaborators.
tools.name: Data Dictionary Generator (DDG)

Features include real-time collaboration, digital publishing, and easy sharing, all of which come in an intuitive, drag-and-drop interface. Upgrade to a professional account for increased storage space and access to additional templates.

It imports data from academic publisher websites and from databases such as PubMed, Google Scholar, Google Books, and arXiv. Paperpile can retrieve and store publication PDF files to the user's Google Drive account.

tools.detail: The Open Science Framework (OSF) is a free, open source tool designed to help researchers manage the entire research workflow: planning, execution, reporting, archiving and discovery. It is part collaboration software and part version control system. The OSF can be used to manage individual projects or large collaborative ones. Privacy and sharing settings allow for fine-grained control over access to files and materials stored on the platform - share privately with collaborators or publicly with the community at large. Each project, contributor, and file on the OSF is given a persistent unique identifier, making all research products citable. The platform also mints DOIs and ARKs through DataCite. A collaborative wiki allows contributors to work on writing materials simultaneously.API connections with other services (Github, Dropbox, Box, Dataverse, Google Drive, figshare, Zotero, Mendeley, Amazon S3) allow researchers to connect other services they already use in order to see all their materials in one place. The OSF also offers a registry for preregistering research projects and/or analysis plans.
tools.name: Open Science Framework

tools.detail: InqScribe is a low-cost, easy-to-use software for creating transcripts from video or audio files. It has a lot of simple customization features which make it easy to use, but not a lot of extra stuff that might bog a new user down. It's best for transcription, but it can also be used for creating subtitles for videos (it can be set up to export a video with the transcript overlaid on it during playback) and even for coding data (best for codes that do not need durations associated with them). It exports to a range of formats (like CSV) for easy analysis.

tools.detail: Lynks provides an easy to use, in-browser tool that helps you to create your own networks. Lynks is an initiative by Centre for Innovation, part of Leiden University (Campus The Hague). The software has been developed in 2014 in co-creation, with expertise from Dr. Eelke Heemskerk from University of Amsterdam. The software development has been supported by the financial contributions from the European Union Fund for Regional Development (EFRO) and the Municipality of The Hague.

tools.detail: SentimentBuilder is an online tool that performs text analytics on emails, reviews, feedback, chat data or any unstructured texts via Natural Language Processing. It's the only tool where you can upload a file for processing and then visually view the results in a Sankey Flow Report to quickly identify trends, issues and strengths and then customize each view, save and share! Export any result for your own offline analysis! Try the Always Free version today and upload your own data or try one of our sample files.
tools.name: SentimentBuilder.com

tools.detail: Eris Solver is a free crowd-solver for complex problems. It implements an innovative way to solve complex problems by adapting brainstorming technique to a Problem Tree Analysis and by channelling Collective Intelligence. When simple problem may require a unique solution to be solved, Complex problems behave differently and multiple solutions are sometimes necessary to solve them. On the contrary to simple problem that may not need further deepening, a complex problem may be broken up in multiple small ones that help us understand the big picture. Every branch of the issue tree represent a different aspect of the problem, problems can be decomposed this way until reaching the bottom line where solutions to the ultimate sub-issues are added. Eris Solver uses an interdisciplinary approach and users are allocated into six major areas of expertise
tools.name: Eris Solver - Free Crowdsolver for Complex Problems

tools.detail: STACK is an extensible social media research toolkit designed to collect, process, and store data from online social networks. The toolkit is an ongoing project via the Syracuse University iSchool, and currently supports the Twitter Streaming API. Collecting from Facebook public pages and Twitter search API are under development. The toolkit architecture is modular and supports extending. Basic Linux / Mac command line skills needed.To learn more: https://github.com/bitslabsyr/stack
tools.name: STACKS

tools.detail: This software scans one or many Word DOCX, text and text-like files (e.g. HTML and XML files) and counts the number of occurrences of the different words or phrases. There is no limit on the size of an input text file. The words/phrases which are found can be displayed alphabetically or by frequency.  The program can be told to allow or disallow words with numerals, hyphens, apostrophes, underscores or colons, to ignore words which are short or which occur infrequently, and to ignore words (e.g., common words such as 'the', a.k.a. stop words) contained in a specified file.  It can also count only words or phrases in a specified list (optionally with pattern-matching).  Results can be exported to Excel for further processing. The program works with text in most European languages, and supports the use of regular expressions for specifying words/phrases to count.
tools.name: Hermetic Word Frequency Counter Advanced Version

tools.detail: This software scans a Word DOCX file or a text file (including HTML and XML files) with text encoded via ANSI or UTF-8 and counts the frequencies of different words. The words which are found and displayed can be ordered alphabetically or by frequency. Characters which can appear in words can be specified, so the program can be told to allow or disallow words with numerals, hyphens, apostrophes, underscores or colons, to ignore words which are short or which occur infrequently, to treat upper/lower case as significant or not, and to ignore words (e.g., common words such as 'this', a.k.a. stop words) contained in a specified file.  This software may be used with text in most European languages.  The language of the text is detected automatically and (if supported) the corresponding stop words file is optionally loaded.  Results can be exported to Excel for further processing.  There is also an Advanced Version with greater functionality.
tools.name: Hermetic Word Frequency Counter

tools.detail: OHMS (Oral History Metadata Synchronizer) inexpensively and efficiently enhances access to oral history by providing users with word-level search capability and a time-correlated transcript or indexed interview connecting the textual search term to the corresponding moment in the recorded interview online.OHMS is an open source,  web-based application designed to improve the user experience you provide for oral history, no matter what CMS or repository you use.  There are 2 main components of the OHMS systemOHMS Application: The OHMS application is where the work is done.  This is the back-end, web-based application where interviews are imported, and metadata is created.  In the OHMS application transcripts are time-coded and/or interviews are indexed.  Upon completion, the interview record (including the synchronized transcript and/or time-coded index) are exported as an XML file.  When located on a web server, the OHMS XML file is what interfaces with your content management system through the OHMS Viewer. OHMS Viewer: The OHMS viewer is the user interface of ohms.   When an interview is called by the repository, the OHMS viewer loads, calling select interview level metadata and the intra interview level metadata created in the OHMS Application from the corresponding xml file.
tools.name: Oral History Metadata Synchronizer

Combine Catmandu modules with web application frameworks such as PSGI/Plack, document stores such as MongoDB and full text indexes such as Solr to create a rapid development environment for digital library services such as institutional repositories and search engines.In the http://librecat.org/ project it is our goal to provide an open source set of programming components to build up digital libraries services suited to your local needs.Read an in depth introduction into Catmandu programming at https://github.com/LibreCat/Catmandu/wiki/Introduction.

Islandora was originally developed by the University of Prince Edward Island's Robertson Library, but is now implemented and contributed to by an ever-growing international community.
