tools.detail:
HyperStudio’s Chronos Timeline is designed specifically for needs in the humanities and social sciences to represent time-based data. Chronos allows scholars and students to dynamically present historical data in a flexible online environment. Switching easily between vertical and horizontal orientations, researchers can quickly scan large number of events, highlight and filter events based on subject matter or tags, and recontextualize historical data. The Chronos Timeline is one component in HyperStudio’s emerging Repertoire platform and can easily be integrated with other tools such as faceted browsers, maps, and visualization modules.

Built in JavaScript on top of an extendable object-oriented architecture, Chronos is a flexible jQuery plug-in using the powerful jQuery library. Chronos is notable for its dynamic scaling, which allows the user to drill down into time periods to explore and compare events. Chronos connects flexibly to data sources via the JSON open standard, and will support XML data structures in a future version. Repertoire Chronos Timeline is currently in beta stage and will be released as free software under the GNU General Public License.
tools.name: Chronos Timeline

Open Source Geospatial Content Management System

It is designed to be extended and modified, and can be integrated into existing platforms.

tools.name: Text Analyzer

tools.detail:
TerraME is a programming environment for spatial dynamical modelling. It supports cellular automata, agent-based models, and network models running in 2D cell spaces. TerraME provides an interface to TerraLib geographical database, allowing models direct access to geospatial data. Its modelling language has in-built functions that makes it easier to develop multi-scale and multi-paradigm models for environmental applications.

Two important innovations in TerraME are its use of anisotropic spaces and of hybrid automata models. Anisotropic spaces arise when modeling natural and human-related phenomena. For example, land settlers in a new area do not occupy all places at the same time. They follow roads and rivers, leading to an anisotropic pattern. Anisotropic spaces are implemented in TerraME using Generalized Proximity Matrices (GPM). The GPM is an extension of the usual definition of the spatial relations and include a combination of neighborhood measures in the absolute space and in the relative space.

A hybrid automaton is an abstract model for a system whose behavior has discrete and continuous parts. It extends the idea of finite automata to allow continuous change to take place between transitions. Adopting hybrid automata in spatial dynamical models allows complex models which include critical transitions.
tools.name: TerraME

tools.detail:
The SSELab is an extensible platform for the development and application of software engineering techniques and concepts.

The SSELab provides basic project hosting services such as a version control system and a project management and bug-tracking tool as well as advanced software engineering services such as code generators for model-based software engineering.
tools.name: SSELab

tools.detail:
Code Bubbles is a front end to Eclipse designed to simplify programming by making it easy for the programmer to define and use working sets. Working sets here consist of the group of functions, documentation, notes, and other information that a programmer needs to accomplish a particular programming task such as adding a feature or fixing a bug.

Code Bubbles accomplishes this by providing compact function-based views of the code (all backed by the underlying files) that are displayed in bubbles and that are easily moved around and manipulated on the screen. The bubbles are fully editable. A large bubble area lets the programmer set up different working sets simultaneously and easily move between them.

In addition to providing facilities for editing and understanding code, the Code Bubbles front end provides facilities for debugging and testing programs.
tools.name: Code Bubbles

tools.detail:
The “CINCO SCCE Meta Tooling Framework” is a generator-driven development environment for domain-specific graphical modeling tools. It is based on the Eclipse Modeling Framework and Graphiti Graphical Tooling Infrastructrure, but aims to hide much of their complexity and intricate APIs.

A graphical modeling tool developed with CINCO is completely generated from an intuitive higher-level abstract specification language. Semantics-inducing parts of the tool that are difficult to define in an abstract declarative way (such as model interpreters, transformations, or code generators) are written in Java against a simple model-based API. CINCO handles the inclusion of the right buttons in the GUI that trigger those actions.

Furthermore, CINCO supports the integration of the Java Application Building Center (jABC) into the development process, so that even people with little or no programming experience can express model behavior in a process-oriented fashion.
tools.name: Cinco

tools.detail:
Social media research software that provides true understanding of how people feel about any topic being discussed on the social web.

Fully customize and white label all your social data projects

Integrate social data and text analysis into your business critical applications.
tools.name: Infegy

tools.detail: Community textual editing tool that runs as a service over the web. Alllows one to see manuscript image and edit the XML. Also provides collation tools.
tools.name: Textual Communities

tools.detail: Logic Pro X is an advanced music production application that gives you everything you need to create amazing music. Offering a massive library of sounds and innovative features like Drummer, Flex Pitch, Smart Controls, and MIDI plug-ins, Logic Pro X makes it easy to compose, record, edit, and mix professional-quality tracks.
tools.name: Logic Pro X

tools.detail:
A free web app to take the pain out of transcribing recorded interviews.


No more switching between Quicktime and Word.

Pause, rewind and fast-forward without taking your hands off the keyboard.

Interactive timestamps to navigate through your transcript with.

Automatically saved to your browser's storage every second.

Private - your audio file and transcript never leave your computer.

Export to Markdown, plain text and Google Docs.

Video file support with integrated player.

Open source under the MIT license.
tools.name: oTranscribe

tools.detail:
OSoMe (awe•some) is a joint project of the Indiana University Network Science Institute (IUNI) and the Center for Complex Networks and Systems Research (CNetS), aimed to study information diffusion in social media. Here we highlight findings, publications, and resources. Use our tools to explore how ideas spread through online social networks.

Hoaxy: Visualize the spread of claims and fact checking.

Botometer: Check how bot-like a Twitter user behaves.

Fakey: PLay this game to learn to recognize fake news on your social feed.

Trends: Compare when memes gain and lose popularity.

Networks: Explore who is discussing a meme and what memes are related.

Maps: Examine where people are talking about a meme over time.

Movies: Generate movies of how conversations about a meme evolve over time.

EchoDemo: Simulation demonstrating how two basic mechanisms of social media can lead to polarized social networks.

Bot Electioneering Volume: Visualizing the activity of likely bots on Twitter around the 2018 US midterm elections.

As well as API and Enhanced Data available.
tools.name: OSoMe

tools.detail: Transform any hand-drawn design into a HTML code with AI.
tools.name: Sketch2Code

tools.detail: ASV Toolbox is a modular collection of tools for the exploration of written language data. They work either on word lists or text and solve several linguistic classification and clustering tasks. The topics covered contain language detection, POS-tagging, base form reduction, named entity recognition, and terminology extraction. On a more abstract level, the algorithms deal with various kinds of word similarity, using pattern based and statistical approaches. The collection can be used to work on large real world data sets as well as for studying the underlying algorithms.
tools.name: ASV Online Toolbox

tools.detail: This tool allows you to search for words in 252 languages and will give you information about that word based on the corpora they have available. Examples of information returned include examples sentences using that word, coocurrences, similar words/phrases, and a mind-map style graph.
tools.name: Leipzig Corpora Collection

tools.detail: MURAL isn’t just for designers. It’s for creatives, developers, managers, project leaders and educators who need a secure, visual workspace to exchange ideas.
tools.name: Mural

tools.detail: REAPER is a complete digital audio production application for computers, offering a full multitrack audio and MIDI recording, editing, processing, mixing and mastering toolset. REAPER supports a vast range of hardware, digital formats and plugins, and can be comprehensively extended, scripted and modified.
tools.name: Reaper

tools.detail:
The Integrated JStylo and Anonymouth Package. Authorship recognition analysis tool
- Version: 2.9.0
tools.name: JSAN

tools.detail:
The Integrated JStylo and Anonymouth Package. Authorship recognition analysis tool
- Version: 2.9.0
tools.name: JSAN

tools.detail:
The Integrated JStylo and Anonymouth Package. Authorship recognition analysis tool
- Version: 2.9.0
tools.name: JSAN

tools.detail: FactoMineR is an R package dedicated to multivariate Exploratory Data Analysis. It is developed and maintained by François Husson, Julie Josse, Sébastien Lê, d'Agrocampus Rennes, and J. Mazet.
tools.name: FactoMiner

tools.detail: TRACER is a suite of 700 algorithms, whose features can be combined to create the optimal formula for detecting those words, sentences and ideas that have been reused across texts. Created by Marco Büchler, TRACER is designed to facilitate research in text reuse detection and many have made use of it to identify plagiarism in a text, as well as verbatim and near verbatim quotations, paraphrase and even allusions. The thousands of feature combinations that TRACER supports allow to investigate not only contemporary texts, but also complex historical texts where reuse is harder to spot.
tools.name: TRACER

tools.detail: Colaboratory is a Google research project created to help disseminate machine learning education and research. It's a Jupyter notebook environment that requires no setup to use and runs entirely in the cloud
tools.name: Colaboratory

tools.detail: It is a sentiment analysis program. Automatic sentiment analysis of up to 16,000 social web texts per second with up to human level accuracy for English - other languages available or easily added.SentiStrength estimates the strength of positive and negative sentiment in short texts, even for informal language.SentiStrength can also report binary (positive/negative), trinary (positive/negative/neutral) and single scale (-4 to +4) results. SentiStrength was originally developed for English and optimised for general short social web texts but can be configured for other languages and contexts by changing its input files - some variants are demonstrated below.
tools.name: SentiStrength

tools.detail:
SentiStrength is a sentiment analysis (opinion mining) program. SentiStrength estimates the strength of positive and negative sentiment in short texts. It is ideal for short texts like tweets.
There is an online version and a downloadable Java version which has more options. 
It is stated to be able to analyse 16,000 tweets per second. To enter multiply short test, each text has to be put on a new line. SentiStrength will give a rating of the positive and negative sentiment strength for each line in a generated text file.
tools.name: SentiStrength

tools.detail:
Google Colab is an online platform hosted by Google to write, run and share code. Just like a Jupyter notebook environment but hosted entirely in the cloud by Google. Python code can be executed without any setup or installation on your computer.
Its outputs are not limited to text for it can produce very rich interactive visualisations with the many visualisation libraries it supports. Notebooks are easily shared in Google drive and Github. It has links to a bank of shared code and tutorials. With Colab the code are run on Google servers which usually offer better processing power than personal computer.
tools.name: Google Colab

tools.detail: The TextRazor helps you extract and understand the Who, What, Why and How from your tweets, email, news stories, legal documents. It locates keywords and groups them into categories like: topic, business, organisation, field of study, people, location. It helps to get an idea what the document is talking about and who are the main people and things involved. It is web based and access is through an API.
tools.name: TextRazor

tools.detail: Cowo reads a text file, detect frequent words contained in it, and find the connections between these frequent words. Cowo creates several files, two of which are really important (a "map" file and a "network" file). These two files are read with VosViewer to produce a map of the most frequent words, arranged according to how frequently they are connected in the same text
tools.name: Cowo

tools.detail: CasualConc is a concordance program that runs natively on macOS 10.11 or later. The current version (2.0 or later) can generate Key Word in Context concordance lines, word clusters, collocation analysis, and word count. This program is only tested with English text just because that is the only language but technically, it should be able to handle any language macOS can. This new version (2.0) has visualization functions using the statistical environment R (needs to be installed separately). It works best with plain text files (.txt) encoded in ASCII or UTF-8, but can handle other file types and other encodings.  Reading non-plain text files will take more time to process.  PDF files should be text-embedded.
tools.name: CasualConc

tools.detail: Automatic stress and relaxation strength detection. It follows the same working principle as its sister tool SensiStrength. It estimates the amount of stress and relaxation in social media text like tweets.
tools.name: TensiStrength

tools.detail:
Semantria is a sentiment analysis tool mainly destined for cooperate customers. Their tool does the following tasks:Text Analytics, Machine Learning, Sentiment Analysis,Named Entity Extraction, Categorization, Intention Extraction and
Summarization. They also offer company packs in which the tools are fine tuned to produce more accurate results for the specific company.
tools.name: Semantria

tools.detail: An R interface for Multidimensional Text and Questionnaire Analysis.
tools.name: IRaMuTeQ

tools.detail:
CATMA 6.0 is a free online tool that helps you to annotate, interpret, analyze and visualize text.  CATMA stands for Computer Assisted Text Markup and Analysis. It is an update from CATMA 5. With CATMA 6.0 you can:
-Upload your own corpus and share it with others to work collaboratively.
-Annotate your texts in an undogmatic fashion. Where required: multiple, overlapping, short, extensive, discontinuous or even in contradictory variants can be used.
-Develop your own tagset or import an existing one.
-Choose from several interactive visualizations for your data. There are word clouds, graphs and networks visualizations.
tools.name: CATMA 6.0

tools.detail: Manifold Scholarship is an open-source publishing platform that enables authors and publishers a means to showcase and enhance the electronic content they already produce in their existing workflows: texts are displayed in a responsive, elegant reader crafted for all modern browsers and devices—desktop and mobile. Powerful built-in annotation and commenting systems allow readers to annotate, highlight, discuss, cite, and share passages from any Manifold text. Resources that are foundational to a particular discussion but that are often tabled because of physical, technical, logistic, or legal limitations can be layered dynamically and directly onto the digital text. And with Manifold, a new kind of publication is possible, one where authors create projects that grow iteratively and that are published online as they are created and then later in print, when they have been codified as versions of record. In short, Manifold transforms scholarly publications into living digital works.
tools.name: Manifold

tools.detail: guiti
tools.name: TEST

tools.detail:
WebLicht is an execution environment for automatic annotation of text corpora. Linguistic tools such as tokenizers, part of speech taggers, and parsers are encapsulated as web services, which can be combined by the user into custom processing chains. The resulting annotations can then be visualized in an appropriate way, such as in a table or tree format.
It is often the case that a tool relies on one or more annotation layers to exist in the input data before it can begin processing. WebLicht can assist the user in building a processing chain by determining which tools are able to operate on the data at any given point and offering only those tools as options to add to the chain.

There are 2 modes for building tool chains:
Easy Mode lets you choose pre-defined processing chains
Advanced Mode allows you to build customized tool chains.

Login is required to use the tools and corpora. Login with email addresses from most recognized European universities will be automatically accepted. Individuals with a Non-European email address need to create an account with clarin.eu

Developed by the German language resource infrastructure (D-SPIN) and Common language resources and technology infrastructure (CLARIN)
tools.name: WebLicht

tools.detail: It is a set of tools created by the Polish branch of Common the Language Resource and Technology Infrastructure (CLARIN) mainly for the analysis of Polish text. It has many Natural Language Processing (NLP)  tools among which are verb annotations, named entity recognition, phrase parser, and spacial expression recognition. Some of the tools can be used for German and English.
tools.name: CLARIN-PL

tools.detail: The PDB-trained dependency parsing models for Polish is a parsing tool trained on the Polish Dependency Bank (which consists of 22,208 trees and 351,406 tokens). It does part-of-speech tagging, lemmatisation, dependency parsing, and semantic role labeling.
tools.name: PDB-trained dependency parsing models for Polish

tools.detail: UDPipe is a trainable pipeline for tokenization, tagging, lemmatization and dependency parsing of CoNLL-U files. UDPipe is language-agnostic and can be trained given annotated data in CoNLL-U format. Trained models are provided for nearly all UD treebanks. UDPipe is available as a binary for Linux/Windows/OS X, as a library for C++, Python, Perl, Java, C#, and as a web service. Third-party R CRAN package also exists.
tools.name: UDPipe

tools.detail:
Nerf is a statistical named entity recognition (NER) tool based on linear-chain conditional random fields (CRFs). It has been adapted to recognize tree-like structures of NEs (i.e., with recursively embedded NEs) by using the joined label tagging method which -- for a particular sentence -- works as follows:

CRF model is used to determine the most probable sequence of labels,
Extended IOB method is used to decode the sequence into a forerst of NEs.
The extended IOB method also provides the inverse encoding function which is needed during the model training.
tools.name: Nerf

tools.detail:
Concraft-pl, a morphosyntactic tagger for the Polish language based on conditional random fields. The tool is coupled with Morfeusz, a morphosyntactic analyzer for Polish, which represents both morphosyntactic and segmentation ambiguities in the form of a directed acyclic graph (DAG).

As for now, the tagger doesn't provide any lemmatisation capabilities. As a result, it may output multiple interpretations (all related to the same morphosyntactic tag, but with different lemmas) for some known words, while for the out-of-vocabulary words it just outputs orthographic forms as lemmas.
tools.name: Concraft-pl 2.0

tools.detail: Software for corpus linguists and text/data mining enthusiasts. The CorpusExplorer combines over 50 interactive visualizations under a user-friendly interface. Routine tasks such as text acquisition, cleaning or tagging are completely automated. The simple interface supports the use in university teaching and leads users/students to fast and substantial results. The CorpusExplorer is open for many standards (XML, CSV, JSON, R, etc.) and also offers its own software development kit (SDK)
tools.name: CorpusExplorer

tools.detail:
forTEXT is a free web service, which helps scholars who are interested in the Digital
Humanities to choose digital methods and tools according to their research setting. forTEXT is especially designed for scholars with no or little experience in the field of Digital Humanities. The focus currently lies on literature studies and language, but will be broadened in the future. forTEXT provides scientific insights into traditions and techniques of the Digital Humanities and offers video and text tutorials as well as teaching materials.
Currently, forTEXT offers content in German, but is going to be translated into English and other languages soon.
tools.name: forTEXT

tools.detail: SPSS  is software for managing data and calculating a wide variety of statistics.  It delivers a robust set of features that lets your organization extract actionable insights from its data.
tools.name: Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS)

tools.detail: quanteda is an R package for managing and analyzing textual data. The package is designed for R users needing to apply natural language processing to texts, from documents to final analysis. It is free and open source. Some of its functions are: Tokenizing, corpus building, topic modeling, visualizations, text similarity measures.
tools.name: Quanteda

tools.detail: The Digital DNA (DDNA) Toolbox is a set of methods developed to support scientists in making sense of online data. In particular, it is designed for assessing the reliability of accounts and content (e.g., detecting fake and bot accounts) in online social networks (OSNs). Its main use is to detect fake and bot accounts.
tools.name: Digital DNA

tools.detail: It is a website that contains free to use templates built with HTML5 and CSS3. The templates are released under creative commons and can be modified. They are responsive and adapt to mobile and desktop use.
tools.name: HTMLUP

tools.detail: Templates to build single page websites. Ideal for personal websites to show personal work or as a landing page.The websites built can be viewed on any screen size. It is free to use but the many templates require pro membership which has a fee.
tools.name: carrd.co

tools.detail: Templated is a website that offers free to use templates in HTML and CSS3 for website development. It currently has 867 fully responsive templates. The template usually contains at least one or more HTML files, a stylesheet, and optionally a few support images and scripts.
tools.name: Templated

tools.detail:
InVisionapp is basically a prototyping tool that allows you to create clickable versions of your design.

It works in early stages of your projects, when you have still mockups, or to create minimum viable product (MVP) to test or to present to customers.
InVisionapp is very advanced, it allows you also to share projects with your team, comment screens, create animations and transitions and interact with most common design tools as Sketch and Photoshop.
tools.name: InVisionapp

tools.detail: Previously known as Agisoft PhotoScan, Agisoft Metashape is a stand-alone software product that performs photogrammetric processing of digital images and generates 3D spatial data to be used in GIS applications, cultural heritage documentation, and visual effects production as well as for indirect measurements of objects of various scales.
tools.name: Agisoft Metashape

tools.detail: Sketchfab is a platform to publish, share, discover, buy and sell 3D, VR and AR content. It provides a viewer based on the WebGL and WebVR technologies that allows users to display 3D models on the web, to be viewed on any mobile browser, desktop browser or Virtual Reality headset. Its 3D viewer  can be embedded on external websites, notably on Facebook. It currently has more than 3 million 3D models of which about 300,000 are free.
tools.name: Sketchfab

tools.detail: Kubity is a cloud-based 3D communication tool that works on desktop computers, the web, smartphones, tablets, augmented reality gear, and virtual reality glasses. Kubity is powered by several proprietary 3D processing engines including "Paragone" and "Etna" that prepare the 3D file for transfer over mobile devices. 3D images can be uploaded and enhanced and used in an artificial reality environment. It also has augmented reality features. It can be used in architecture, interior design, engineering, product design, film and video games among others. The majority of its users create 3D models using SketchUp or Autodesk Revit software.
tools.name: Kubity

tools.detail: a-Frame is a web framework for building virtual reality (VR) experiences. A-Frame is based on top of HTML, making it simple to get started. But A-Frame is not just a 3D scene graph or a markup language; the core is a powerful entity-component framework that provides a declarative, extensible, and composable structure to three.js.
tools.name: A-frame

tools.detail: ThingLink is a free and user -friendly digital tool that provides users the ability to turn any image into an interactive graphic. It allows you to make your images, videos, and 360 content interactive with text, links, images, videos and over 70 call to actions, creating memorable experiences for audiences. The web tool and the app allow for teachers and students to provide information in a visual format. It can be considered as a form of annotation of visual multimedia content.
tools.name: Thinglink

tools.detail:
Bl.ock is a simple viewer for sharing code examples hosted on GitHub Gist. For example, if your Gist URL is:
https://gist.github.com/mbostock/1353700
Replace “gist.github.com” with “bl.ocks.org” in the URL to view it:
https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/1353700
It has configurations to determine how your block will be displayed. Bl.ock runs your visualization code (usually is d3) and displays it, unlike github that only displays the code.
tools.name: bl.ock

tools.detail: TextBlob is a Python (2 and 3) library for processing textual data. It provides a simple API for diving into common natural language processing (NLP) tasks such as part-of-speech tagging, noun phrase extraction, sentiment analysis, classification, translation, and more.
tools.name: TextBlob

tools.detail: Data Illustrator aims to make visualization creation as easy as creating an illustration in a design tool like Adobe Experience Design or Bohemian Sketch. Visualizations are created without programming. It was created from a research collaboration between Adobe Systems Inc. and Georgia Institute of Technology.
tools.name: Data-illustrator

tools.detail:
spaCy is an open-source software library for advanced natural language processing, written in the programming languages Python and Cython. The library is published under the MIT license and currently offers statistical neural network models for English, German, Spanish, Portuguese, French, Italian, Dutch and multi-language NER, as well as tokenization for various other languages.

Unlike NLTK, which is widely used for teaching and research, spaCy focuses on providing software for production usage. As of version 1.0, spaCy also supports deep learning workflows that allow connecting statistical models trained by popular machine learning libraries like TensorFlow, Keras, Scikit-learn or PyTorch. spaCy's machine learning library, Thinc, is also available as a separate open-source Python library. It features convolutional neural network models for part-of-speech tagging, dependency parsing and named entity recognition, as well as API improvements around training and updating models, and constructing custom processing pipelines.
tools.name: spaCy

tools.detail: Intelligent Archive is a Java application for stylometry, or computational and statistical analysis of style in texts, produced by the University of Newcastle's Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing (CLLC). It can handle corpora of plain text, HTML, XML and TEI texts. IA enables you to easily organise texts into sets, manage metadata, generate word frequencies, handle XML tags, and split texts in various ways to generate results that can be exported for further analysis in statistical software. It includes some experimental stylometry techniques developed at the CLLC and special features for handling literary texts such as generating word frequencies for speaking characters in plays.
tools.name: Intelligent Archive

tools.detail: Congree provides linguistic tools which act as assistants to authors in business. It provides assistance for authors of technical and marketing documentation to ensure correct use of corporate language. It is installed as an add on to popular word editing programs like Microsoft Excel, Word, PowerPoint, oxygen XML editor, among others.
tools.name: congree

tools.detail:
Gensim is an open-source library for unsupervised topic modeling and natural language processing, using modern statistical machine learning.
Gensim is implemented in Python and Cython. Gensim is designed to handle large text collections using data streaming and incremental online algorithms, which differentiates it from most other machine learning software packages that target only in-memory processing. Gensim includes streamed parallelized implementations of fastText, word2vec and doc2vec algorithms, as well as latent semantic analysis (LSA, LSI, SVD), non-negative matrix factorization (NMF), latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA), tf-idf and random projections.
tools.name: gensim

tools.detail:
WordArt.com is an online word cloud art creator that enables you to create amazing and unique word cloud art with ease.
Professional quality results can be achieved in no time at all, even for users with no prior knowledge of graphic design. Choose from a huge selection of word cloud designs arranged into many theme categories.
tools.name: Word Art

tools.detail: Create your own nostalgic Microsoft WordArt and party like it's 1995. Make your own custom word art easily.
tools.name: Word Art (MakeWordArt)

tools.detail: Cool Text is a FREE graphics generator for web pages and anywhere else you need an impressive logo without a lot of design work. Simply choose what kind of image you would like. Then fill out a form and you'll have your own custom image created on the fly.
tools.name: CoolText

tools.detail: Crystal-clear Skype video & audio recording on Windows. Revolutionary editing console. Create complete video production from Skype video calls. Create MP4 or WMV files suitable for sharing with others. Record each party in the video call to separate files for greater control over mixing. Edit your videos in split-screen (side by side), or this side / other side camera views with our Post-Production Console.  Add subtitles and more.
tools.name: VodBurner

tools.detail: Built inside Juxta Editions is the HumEdit editor. HumEdit provides an easy to learn environment for transcribing, editing, and marking up text. Whether you are working with a printed page or a manuscript leaf, you will find that you spend more time to focused on your objects of study with HumEdit.
tools.name: JuxtaEditions (HumEdit)

tools.detail:
Archivematica is a web- and standards-based, open-source application which allows your institution to preserve long-term access to trustworthy, authentic and reliable digital content.
Archivematica is an integrated suite of open-source software tools that allows users to process digital objects from ingest to access in compliance with the ISO-OAIS functional model. Users monitor and control ingest and preservation micro-services via a web-based dashboard. Archivematica uses METS, PREMIS, Dublin Core, the Library of Congress BagIt specification and other recognized standards to generate trustworthy, authentic, reliable and system-independent Archival Information Packages (AIPs) for storage in your preferred repository.
tools.name: Archivematica

tools.detail:
PDF Expert is a tool for mac computers used to work with PDF files. With PDF Expert you can:
-Highlight text and make annotations. 
-Fill forms like tax reports.
-Sign documents.
-Edit PDF documents directly. Edit text, images and links.
-Reduce the file size of PDF documents.
-Create new pages.
-Merge PDF documents
-Extract pages
tools.name: PDF expert

tools.detail: A.nnotate is the flagship product of Textensor Limited which was incorporated in Edinburgh, Scotland in 2005.Today A.nnotate is used online by thousands of individuals and groups who need to store or share comments on documents, web pages or images.
tools.name: A.nnotate

tools.detail: iAnnotate is a tool that works on iPhone and iPad. It is used to read, markup and share documents and web-pages. Notes can be added with pen or with the typewriter.
tools.name: iAnnotate

tools.detail:
VoodooPad is a place to write down your notes and thoughts. Ideas, images, lists, passwords, your mom's apple pie recipe. Include anything you need to keep track of and organize, and VoodooPad will grow with you without getting in the way.

Drag and drop folders, PDFs, applications, or URLs into VoodooPad, and they will link up just like on the web. And with powerful search, nothing will be lost or out of reach. It has an encryption toll to keep sensitive information like passwords secure.
tools.name: VoodooPad

tools.detail: MIX 2.0 is a sophisticated statistical add-in for performing meta-analysis in Excel. There is a free ‘Lite’ version and a premium ‘Pro’ version. Both can be downloaded for free, but the Pro version requires an activation with a license code that can be purchased. It works only on windows on Excel 2007 and later. Basic knowledge of Excel is required.
tools.name: MIX 2.0

tools.detail:
The Layar Reality Browser is a free iPhone or Android augmented reality app that lets users look through their mobile device's camera to see “real time digital information (layers) on top of reality.” Some examples of layers are Architecture 3D, Foursquare, Google local search, Trulia, Twitter, Wikipedia and Yellowpages. The app itself is an augmented reality browser and users must download specific layers in order to view and access content. Most layers are free downloads, others cost around $2.00.
Individuals and businesses can use Layar to add links, videos, audio, etc to their flyers, logos or products. The product is scanned with a mobile phone camera through the Layar app.
The company seems to be bankrupted and Layar might not be in further development.
tools.name: Layar

tools.detail:
Historypin is a digital, user-generated archive of historical photos, videos, audio recordings and personal recollections. Users are able to use the location and date of their content to "pin" it to Google Maps. Where Google Street View is available, users can overlay historical photographs and compare it with the contemporary location.

This content can be added and explored online and via a series of Smartphone applications
tools.name: Historypin

tools.detail: I-Analyzer is a service created by the Digital Humanities Lab of Utrecht University. It has corpora that can be search with many filtering options. It has the option of different visualisations of the search results. It currently has three corpora with most contents in Dutch and Hebrew. It is free to use upon registration.
tools.name: I-Analyzer

tools.detail: A service facilitating online communication via both VoIP and text channels.
tools.name: Discord

tools.detail: Prezi is a cloud-based tool, ideal to showcase your projects with an innovative touch.
tools.name: Prezi

tools.detail: Prezi is a cloud-based tool, ideal to showcase your projects with an innovative touch.
tools.name: Prezi

tools.detail:
"Twitter Network Visualization Analytics Tool

Visualize and explore interactions, build critical relationships and find out who is carrying today’s conversations. Find new hashtags and followers that you might have missed otherwise."
tools.name: Mentionmapp Analytics Tool

tools.detail:
"Twitter Network Visualization Analytics Tool

Visualize and explore interactions, build critical relationships and find out who is carrying today’s conversations. Find new hashtags and followers that you might have missed otherwise."
tools.name: Mentionmapp Analytics Tool

tools.detail:
"Twitter Network Visualization Analytics Tool

Visualize and explore interactions, build critical relationships and find out who is carrying today’s conversations. Find new hashtags and followers that you might have missed otherwise."
tools.name: Mentionmapp Analytics Tool

tools.detail:
"Twitter Network Visualization Analytics Tool

Visualize and explore interactions, build critical relationships and find out who is carrying today’s conversations. Find new hashtags and followers that you might have missed otherwise."
tools.name: Mentionmapp Analytics Tool

tools.detail: It is a set of code in Python that do the common things that humanists do to text as they prepare it for analysis. In starts with loading the text and proceeds to cleaning and dividing the text and preparing it for analysis. It also has a scraping tool to get data directly from websites. The user that has to do some basic modifications of text can just do some modifications of the code provided.
tools.name: Humanists Natural Language Processing Cookbook

tools.detail: KH Coder is a free software for quantitative content analysis or text mining. It is also utilized for computational linguistics. You can analyze Catalan, Chinese (simplified), Dutch, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Russian, Slovenian and Spanish text with KH Coder.
tools.name: KH Coder

tools.detail: Alteryx is an online commercial data analysis service. Among its capabilities are optical character recognition, sentiment analysis, and topic modeling with Text Mining. You can quickly build predictive models without coding through its intuitive graphical user interface. It has many visualisation options among which is the word cloud.
tools.name: Alteryx

tools.detail:
Sketch Engine is a tool to explore how language works. Its algorithms analyze authentic texts of billions of words (text corpora) to identify instantly what is typical in language and what is rare, unusual or emerging usage. It is also designed for text analysis or text mining applications.

Sketch Engine is used by linguists, lexicographers, translators, students and teachers. It is a first choice solution for publishers, universities, translation agencies and national language institutes throughout the world.

Sketch Engine contains 500 ready-to-use corpora in 90+ languages, each having a size of up to 30 billion words to provide a truly representative sample of language.

Some of its functions are: word sketch, sketch difference, thesaurus, concordance, parallel concordance, wordlist, n-grams, keywords & terms, bilingual term extractiontrends and OneClick Dictionary.
tools.name: Sketch Engine

tools.detail: This is cloud-native Enterprise content management (ECM) with which you can manage content from anywhere, connect information with users everywhere and deliver apps to any device. Alfresco enables businesses to increase worker productivity, govern valuable information and deliver exceptional customer experiences.
tools.name: Alfresco

tools.detail: KonText is a basic web application for querying corpora available within the LINDAT/CLARIAH-CZ project. It allows evaluation of simple and complex queries, displaying their results as concordance lines, computing frequency distribution, calculating association measures for collocations and further work with language data.
tools.name: KonText

tools.detail: tes
tools.name: test

tools.detail:
MassMine is a command line tool designed for researchers to simplify the collection and use of data from online sources such as social media networks. Geared toward novices and power users alike.

Designed for use on personal computers or on headless servers.

Handles the acquisition of API data while managing rate limits imposed by these services.

Makes setting up custom data requests easy, allowing for flexible deployment for individualized research needs.

Creates and manages databases of collected data automatically. This means that all tweets, trends, posts, etc. related to your research questions are saved permanently on your local hard drive.

Designed for long-running data collection projects. MassMine makes it easy to create your own database of social media content spanning days, months, or years.
tools.name: MassMine

tools.detail: It is used for word sense disambiguation. It is used to determine the meaning of an ambiguous word in a given context. It is available as an online tool. It highlights named entities and provides links to the Wikipedia page of the highlighted word.
tools.name: FastSense

tools.detail: LitViz is a tool available online for the visualisation of text-information as a 3D-graph. The algorithm uses multiple techniques from NLP (Natural Language Processing) like Stanford PoS-Tagger, Lemmatizer, Tokenizer and more to generate the necessary dataset for the 3D-function.
tools.name: LitViz

tools.detail:
Text2DDC is an online tool that provides an API which analyzes unstructured text and generates labeled topic classifications based on the Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC). It is available to use online or through an API.
It is currently not working.
tools.name: Text2DDC

tools.detail: It is a set of tools to work with Latin text. It provides a database of Latin texts and a morphological structured Latin Lexicon. All texts are lemmatized and ready for comparative analysis of word frequencies.
tools.name: CompHistSem

tools.detail:
TextImager is a UIMA-based framework that offers a range of NLP and visualization tools by means of a user-friendly GUI. Using TextImager requires no programming skills. It can be used as on online web application.
Note: The tool is presently not functional.
tools.name: TextImager

tools.detail:
TextAnnotator is a web based annotation tool implemented with the JavaScript framework ExtJS and the visualization library d3.js  that can process and annotate NLP documents in UIMA (Unstructured Information Management applications) format. 
TextAnnotator is a framework that offers several annotation tools for generating IMA-compliant training data that can be used to train classifiers in support of the needs of humanities scholars.
Note: The tool is currently not working.
tools.name: TextAnnotator

tools.detail:
VAnnotatoR is a system that massively supports the annotation of multimedia, multimodal networks of linguistic and object-related data in virtual 3D environments.

VAnnotatoR allows for segmenting and linking texts and images with other multimedia, multimodal data to ultimately create spatial hypertexts. It can be used to support concrete technical applications, e.g. the reconstruction of 3D scenes from texts as a preparatory step for the training of Text2Scene systems, or for applications in the digital humanities, such as the spatial reconstruction and linking of historical scenes or biographies with corresponding media content, such as images or 3D reconstructions of historical buildings. The entire system is interactively accessible with VR glasses in Virtual Reality (VR) and can be controlled and experienced accordingly. VAnnotatoR uses TextAnnotator as technological backbone and thus all its functions for annotation, task management, annotation evaluation as well as for collaborative and simultaneous processing of resources. Furthermore, VAnnotatoR uses TextImager to benefit from its NLP routines for automatic text analysis. VAnnotatoR is implemented on the basis of Unity3D and OpenVR and therefore runs with both systems and several VR glasses – it was tested on Oculus Rift, Oculus Rift S, Oculus Quest, HTC Vive and HTC Vive Cosmos under Windows 10.

A demonstration of its usage can be found here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BBUg8mHT0iI
tools.name: VAnnotatoR

tools.detail: The TreeTagger is a program developed by Helmut Schmid at the University of Stuttgart (now at the University of München), for part-of-speech tagging and lemmatization. Language models (known as “parameters”, file extension .par) are supplied on the TreeTagger webpage for using the program with texts in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Russian, Bulgarian, Dutch, Estonian, Finnish, Galician, Latin, Mongolian, Polish, Slovak and Swahili, and models for some other languages are available from sites linked to the TreeTagger webpage. For a language for which no model exists, it is necessary to hand-tag some text, and then run a training program (provided with the TreeTagger) to create the model.
tools.name: TreeTagger

tools.detail: Coggle is an intuitive mind mapping tool that allows for collaboration between its users. It is free for public use and can be accessed in your browser or you can install the app on your Apple or Android device
tools.name: Coggle

tools.detail: Free browser-based tool for the creation and publishing of electronic music.
tools.name: Audiotool

tools.detail: Free browser-based tool for the creation and publishing of electronic music.
tools.name: Audiotool

tools.detail: Piktochart is a visual tool that create infographics, reports and more
tools.name: Piktochart

tools.detail: Second Life is a simulation tool/platform in which allows people to create things beyond their wildest imagination. My review on the tool/platform can be found here: https://www.clomurph.com/2021/02/20/critical-review-of-the-digital-humanities-platform-second-life/
tools.name: Second Life

tools.detail: Second Life is a simulation tool/platform in which allows people to create things beyond their wildest imagination. My review on the tool/platform can be found here: https://www.clomurph.com/2021/02/20/critical-review-of-the-digital-humanities-platform-second-life/
tools.name: Second Life

tools.detail: Test Tool
tools.name: Test Tool by Kamal

tools.detail:
The Nocode app is a suite of data exploration tools (or functions) that can be used by analysts, students, researchers and journalist to analyse text. It currently has 5 functions:
Umigon: sentiment analysis for social media, in English and French.
Cowo: transform your texts into networks. 
Topics: identify the key topics in texts of any language.
Gaze: find the network structure in your list of items.
Organic: distinguish natural from corporate tweets.

It is free to use. It can be used on a browser and the app can be downloaded and installed on a local computer.
tools.name: Nocode app

tools.detail:
A Jupyter notebook that show some methods of comparing documents. The methods included are:
-Document term matrix-TF-IDF-Cosine similarity-Visualizing document similarity with scatterplots-Visualizing document similarity with dendrograms
tools.name: Jupyter notebook: Document similarity

tools.detail: The Literary Field Guide provides an overview of the textual ecology of the text that you are about to read. It identifies mentions of ecological terms in the text and outputs an image that represents the environment the ecological terms of the text suggest. It also outputs the mentions and their frequencies under specific headings (for example: fauna, flora, amphibians, trees, landscapes, etc )
tools.name: The Literary Field Guide

tools.detail:
Netlytic is a community-supported text and social networks analyzer that can automatically summarize and visualize public online conversations on social media sites. It is made for researchers by researchers, no programming/API skills required.

With Netlytic you can: 

capture publicly available posts from social media sites or other sources (Twitter, YouTube, RSS Feed, or text/csv file)
Discover popular topics
Find and explore emerging themes of discussions
Build, visualize and analyze online communication networks using social network analysis
Map geo-coded social media data
tools.name: Netlytic

tools.detail:
Communalytic is a research tool for studying online communities and online discourse.
Communalytic can collect and analyze public data from social media platforms. It uses advanced text and social network analysis techniques to automatically pinpoint toxic and anti-social interactions, identify influencers, map shared interests and the spread of misinformation, and detect signs of possible coordination among seemingly disparate actors.
tools.name: Communalytic

tools.detail:
Recoll is used to search for documents based on their content as well as thier filenames.
Recoll can search documents on many different formats and from a variety of storages (files, archive members, email attachments, etc while transparently handling decompression.
It is free on Linux, open source, and licensed under the GPL.
It is based on the very capable Xapian search engine library, for which it provides a powerful text extraction layer and a complete, yet easy to use, Qt graphical interface.
tools.name: Recoll

tools.detail: Bonsai is a JavaScript graphics library. It also has an online SVG renderer and JavaScript editor called orbit. Currently maintenance of the library seems to have stopped. Demos no longer work
tools.name: Bonsai

tools.detail: FramebyFrame is a basic application to create stopmotion with your webcam. Currently it works with only Mac computers. Many reviewers complained of the app crashing frequently.
tools.name: FramebyFrame

tools.detail:
This is a lightweight and easy to use intuitive tool to make hand-drawn 2D animations. Pencil2D is cross-platform and runs on Windows, macOS, Linux & FreeBSD.

Pencil2D is completely open source and free to use, even commercially!
tools.name: Pencil2D Animation

tools.detail: Storyteller was an environment builded by Amazon to give creators the ability to easily visualize a script as a storyboard or animatic video. As of 25th September 2015, it is no longer available.
tools.name: Storyteller

tools.detail: This are online interactive tools that provide a unique learning experience for users, regardless of their musical training. It can be used to explore algorithmic compositions. The algorithmic process could also be used to create music as users can convert a sequence of integers into sounds.
tools.name: Musicalgorithms

tools.detail: Paperphone is a scholarly project that had as aim to modify the sound/voice during a presentation, i.e. in real time. It was designed to challenge the privileging of text over act in humanities scholarship. Paperphone is a performative platform for scholars to unravel the expressive potential of voice and audio in sharing academic works.
tools.name: Paperphone

tools.detail:
Praat is a free software package for phonetic analysis. Some of the functionalities include spectral analysis (spectrograms)
pitch analysis,
formant analysis,
intensity analysis,
jitter, shimmer, voice breaks
cochleagram,
excitation pattern, speech manipulation, etc
tools.name: Praat

tools.detail: Sonic Visualiser is a free, open-source application for Windows, Linux, and Mac, designed to study a music recording closely. It's designed for musicologists, archivists, signal-processing researchers, and anyone else looking for a friendly way to look at what lies inside the audio file. Its latest release was September 2021. Its main functions are visualisation, analysis, and annotation of music audio recordings.
tools.name: Sonic Visualiser

tools.detail:
Odyssey.js is an open-source tool that allows you to combine maps, narratives, and other multimedia into a beautiful story. You enhance the narrative and multimedia of your stories using Actions (e.g. map movements, video and sound control, or the display or new content) that will let you tell your story in an exciting new way.

Experts can also add custom Templates and Actions by following the contribution guide. The tool is still under development and will include YouTube, Vimeo, Soundcloud, and Twitter based Actions.

The library is open source and freely available to use in your projects.
tools.name: Odyssey

tools.detail: Twine is an open-source tool for telling interactive, nonlinear stories. The users don't need to write code  but they can use variables, conditional logic, images, CSS, and JavaScript to enhance their stories if needed. The story is published in HTML and hence can be shared anywhere online.
tools.name: Twine

tools.detail: The sourcecaster helps users work in the windows command line. It contains short lines of code that can be used to manipulate files for analysis. File types include image, video, text, audio, etc. Below each line of code are explanations that tell what each part of the code does and so the user can modify the code to suite his/her objectives. The sourcecaster relies on contributions from the community. There are currently very few entries.
tools.name: the sourcecaster

tools.detail: The Explainshell website contains 29761 parsed manpages (a form of software documentation) from sections 1 and 8 found in Ubuntu's manpage repository. It used python and some NLTK to parse code to retrieve information and documentation for each part of the code. The user pastes the command line code into the search box and the code is annotated using D.js visualization.
tools.name: Explainshell

tools.detail: All Our Ideas is a research project that seeks to develop a new form of social data collection by combining the best features of quantitative and qualitative methods. Using the power of the web, we are creating a data collection tool that has the scale, speed, and quantification of a survey while still allowing for new information to "bubble up" from respondents as happens in interviews, participant observation, and focus groups.
tools.name: All Our Ideas

tools.detail: CollectiveAccess is free, open-source software for cataloguing and publishing museum and archival collections. The collection can then be published  while requiring (or not) login. It has got built in search function and can display media files. The users can annotate their media files. It has many other functions. Documentation can be found here https://manual.collectiveaccess.org/
tools.name: CollectiveAcces

tools.detail: oldweb.today (OWT) is a system that connects emulated web browsers to web archives, allowing users to browse the old web, today, as it was! On the home page, you can choose what browser you want to run. It has browsers as early as the Mosaic browser.
tools.name: oldweb.today

tools.detail: It is both a set of software and practices that can be used to help organizations and individuals display computer based exhibitions. It includes a variety of human and computer interactions and could be ideal from user(s) interaction with data walls. Its community is made up of a diverse group of individuals that contribute to the design of human computer interactions and experiences with digital exhibitions. They include artists, developers, designers, museum professionals, technologists, and educators. The software if free for use by museums.
tools.name: Open Exhibits

tools.detail: Cosma is a visualization tool that works on Windows and Mac operating systems. It  is available in French and English. Its input are linked  markdown text files and it creates an HTML network visualization of the files. There are many options to customize the visualization. The HTML visualization can be exported and shared unlike others tools in which only the static image of the visualization is share. This means that the data and the tools to explore it are shared simultaneously. Cosma is free to download, use and modify.
tools.name: Cosma

tools.detail:
Archive Alert is an online platform that allows individuals, entities, groups, and organizations to report on archives and/or other cultural material which promotes cultural heritage (audiovisual material, maps, photographs, printed material, newspapers, posters, etc.). The users may report material they are in possession of, or material threatened by ignorance, negligence, or due to lack of expert human resources.
Registered users can report on their own historical documents either to inform archival organizations, or to invite specialized staff to archive, file, preserve and utilize the material. The platform allows for anonymous or eponymous/public registration, and then, depending on the material reported, it automatically informs all organizations/entities that may be concerned.
The platform is free for users-informants and archival organizations; any kind of buying and selling of archival and cultural material is strictly forbidden.
The homepage and introduction pages are in English while the archive report section is only available in Greek. There are currently only two reports of archives in the website.
tools.name: Archive Alert

tools.detail:
Scalar is a free, open source semantic web authoring and publishing tool. It helps long-form authors to produce born digital scholarship online. The tool offers a mixture of standardization and structural flexibility so as to provide the users with a platform where they can assemble media from multiple sources and link it to their writings in different ways. 
 In addition to having a built-in reading interface, Scalar also has an API that permits custom-designed applications to use Scalar content. It encourages improvisation to the data model used by users, especially if the content they are dealing with is structured and small to moderate in size. The platform also supports collaborative authoring and reader commentary.
tools.name: Scalar

tools.detail: PBworks provides a vast range of products focused on collaborative content. The tool provides “unique collaboration capabilities like structured metadata and management reporting”. It has an intuitive interface for knowledge management which is supported by a wiki-style collaboration.
tools.name: PBworks

tools.detail: This tool allows one to run topic models without having to download R or Mallet. The tool runs on any modern web browser. Whilst exhibiting the capacity of statistical computing in Javascript, the tool makes the integration between models and web-based visualizations tighter.
tools.name: jsLDA: In-browser topic modeling

tools.detail: Bichitra is the biggest integrated knowledge site devoted to any author in any language to date. It comprises most versions of nearly all Tagore’s works in Bengali and English. It excludes most letters, speeches, textbooks and translations, except Tagore’s translations from his own Bengali. It includes digital images of virtually all his manuscripts and authoritative print versions (books and journals), 47,520 pages of manuscripts and 91,637 pages of printed books and journals and plain-text transcripts of all these versions. It also acts as a search engine to locate words and phrases in Tagore's works and as a collation engine to compare different versions of a work at three levels: chapter (in a long prose work) or act/scene (in a play); paragraph (in prose) or stanza (in verse). It also has a checklist of the contents of each manuscript and a bibliography of all authoritative manuscript and print versions of each work.
tools.name: Bichitra: Online Tagore Variorum

tools.detail: Tabula lets you upload a (text-based) PDF file into a simple web interface and magically pull tabular data into CSV format.
tools.name: Tabula

tools.detail:
Twint is an advanced Twitter scraping tool written in Python that allows for scraping Tweets from Twitter profiles without using Twitter's API.

Twint utilizes Twitter's search operators to let you scrape Tweets from specific users, scrape Tweets relating to certain topics, hashtags & trends, or sort out sensitive information from Tweets like e-mail and phone numbers. I find this very useful, and you can get really creative with it too.

Twint also makes special queries to Twitter allowing you to also scrape a Twitter user's followers, Tweets a user has liked, and who they follow without any authentication, API, Selenium, or browser emulation.
Recently it looks like Twitter has found a way to limit the number of tweets scraped using twint. Twint also has a visualizer and a desktop app is under development.
tools.name: TWINT - Twitter Intelligence Tool

tools.detail: Saktumiva is a platform for producing and publishing critical editions of Sanskrit texts. Users can produce transcriptions of documents, such as manuscripts or printed editions, and then automatically collate them to produce an apparatus of variants.
tools.name: Saktumiva

tools.detail:
Established with the aim of disseminating and promoting Urdu literature, with a focus on poetry, Rekhta.org is a free website with archival material available in Roman and Devnagari script along with the Urdu script. The website has a large number of features that make it extremely user-friendly and provides the reader unparalleled convenience in the ability to browse, search and find relevant content with its customized powerful search facility. The website allows one to see the translation as well as transliteration of Urdu words to Hindi and English. It also has the unique feature of an in-built glossary that provides the meaning of every word at just a click. In order to give the uninitiated reader a flavour of the diction and pronunciation, a large number of compositions have been recorded in the voice of poets and professionals and have been provided along with the text. The website also has an Urdu dictionary. 
It has started a section of Urdu Shayari for beginners wherein newcomers to the world of Urdu poetry are introduced to relatively easy poetry as well as popular Ghazals and Nazms along with videos of these compositions sung and recited by well known artists and poets. It has also started an initiative to digitize Urdu literature, both poetry and prose, in order to preserve rare and popular Urdu books.  Apart from sourcing books from personal collections of various people, it has also associated with reputed libraries and organizations to digitize their collections.
tools.name: Rekhta

tools.detail:
Rekhta Dictionary is a new initiative of Rekhta Foundation for the promotion and preservation of Urdu language and literature. Since 2011, the Foundation has been running multiple websites including Rekhta, Sufinama, Hindwi, and Aamozish.
The Rekhta Dictionary is a comprehensive collection of Urdu words with their meanings in Urdu, Hindi and English. The words can easily be accessed in three scripts through a high-functioning search engine. Along with detailed meanings, it gives the list of synonyms, antonyms, proverbs, idioms and much more.
This trilingual Urdu dictionary is designed as a resourceful tool for the researchers, poetry-lovers, and general readers irrespective of their familiarity with Urdu script.
tools.name: Rekhta Dictionary

tools.detail: Designed by noted Urdu academics and contemporary poets, Aamozish is an Urdu learning platform, created by the Rekhta Foundation.
tools.name: Aamozish

tools.detail:
A crowdsourced community-based archive, 1947 Partition Archive has been documenting the people's history of the 1947 Partition since 2010. The year 1947 marked the end of British Raj in South Asia and the formation of modern India, Pakistan and (since 1971) Bangladesh, via the Partition of Punjab and Bengal, a globally disruptive event that created one of the largest mass refugee crises of the last century.
The archive has a mapping tool where one can search for persons migrating to and from certain cities during the partition and also zoom in to read their oral histories.
 They have recorded over 10,200 witness oral histories from 14 countries in over 36 languages and dialects, including digital copies of antiquated photographs, documents and images of personal objects of historical value, gathered from personal collections.
tools.name: 1947 Partition Archive

tools.detail:
The interface offers many ways to explore early women writers' engagements with other authors and texts. There are four interconnected "explorer" spaces focused on different aspects of the data: the bibliography, the topics and genres referenced, the intertextual gestures, and the authors in Women Writers Online.
The Bibliography of works quoted, named, cited, or otherwise referenced by the authors in Women Writers Online currently includes more than 3,000 works. 
The Topics & Genres explorer includes referenced texts that range from agriculture to ethics to history to travel writing. 
The Intertextual Gestures explorer supports filtering by the different types of intertextual gestures, the various works that are referenced, the topics and genres of the referenced works, and the WWO source texts and authors.
The Authors in WWO explorer provides a summary view of the intertextual gestures in each of the 440 texts in the Women Writers Online collection.
tools.name: Women Writers: Intertextual Networks

tools.detail: PubPub is a free open source publishing website. Its aim is to facilitate the creation and publishing of knowledge. It is an open-source, hosted, free-to-use content management system designed to help knowledge communities of all types collaboratively create and share knowledge online. PubPub’s flexible, extensible system allows communities to create the dynamic content that best represents their work, whether it’s a traditional academic journal, a book, a repository of interactive documents, a blog, all of the above, or something in between. If needed, PubPub then helps communities integrate their work into academic infrastructure like Crossref and Google Scholar without the need to remake it to conform to legacy expectations of how academic outputs are structured.
tools.name: PubPub

tools.detail: Reviews in Digital Humanities is a pilot of a peer-reviewed journal that facilitates scholarly evaluation of digital humanities work and its outputs. This may include, but is not limited to: digital archives, multimedia or multimodal scholarship, digital exhibits, visualizations, digital games, digital tools, and digital projects. The journal is hosted by PubPub. The journal responds to the challenge of the growth of the number and scale of digital projects outpacing review opportunities in existing journals. As such, it intervenes by bridging a gap in the evaluation of digital projects by arranging for peer review of digital scholarship. Project creators can submit their projects for review.RDH publishes monthly issues with an average of 5 reviews per issue.It also contains a registry of projects, some of which have not yet been reviewed.As of June 2022, Reviews in Digital Humanities has more than 76,800 page views, with 17,350+ unique users from 124 countries. Among fields of study for the projects we have reviewed, 30% of projects are in African diaspora studies, 21% are in Latinx studies, 9% are in Global Indigenous studies, and 19% are in Queer studies. The remaining 21% come from a variety of fields.
tools.name: Reviews in Digital Humanities (RDH)

tools.detail: AUdiAnnotate is a web applications that is used to create IIIF file of audios and videos but adding annotations and/metadata. This makes the audiovisual material more accessible to users since the file can be queried using the metadata. Users will need a GitHub account to access the AudiAnnotate application and to host the files generated. The resulting IIIF object will be made available through an HTML link. The HTML files produced are hosted on GitHib and can be edited to change the way it if displayed. The AudiAnnotate is still active and the applications is constantly being updated. A review of AudiAnnotate can be found at https://reviewsindh.pubpub.org/pub/audiannotate/release/3
tools.name: AudiAnnotate

tools.detail: This is a digital archive that keeps a record of black people both free and enslaved involved in producing  the valued architecture, handcrafts, and decorative arts of the American South. The archive starts in 1619. There are currently hundreds of records of blacks involved in 45 trades. The website has an interactive and searchable map.
tools.name: Black Craftspeople Digital Archive
